Prerequisites: Permission of instructor and successful completion of ENGL 10803 and 20803. Study under faculty supervision which will emphasize writing. Weekly meetings with instructor. (3-6 semester hours, maximum 3 hours per semester.)

Prerequisites: Junior or senior art history majors and minors, with permission of the instructor.  The objective of the internship is to provide the student with the practical experience of working with professionals in an art museum, gallery, or other art-related venue.
Topics may vary each time it is offered.

Prerequisites: A grade of 'C' or better in DSGN 10133 Color and Light Theory.  A series of lectures and laboratory experiments through which students will develop both technical and aesthetic understanding of architectural lighting. Special emphasis on the color metrics, luminaire typologies, photometric analysis, calculations, human centered design, and the lighting design process for both daylight and electrical lighting.

Prerequisites:  A grade of 'C' or better in ARLD 20503. This course is focused upon industry-specific digital media used in architectural lighting. Students will learn how to utilize 2D, 3D, and Building Information Modeling (BIM) to create architectural lighting contract documentation, how to generate daylighting and electric lighting calculations, and how to craft renderings through a blending of by hand and digital techniques.

Prerequisite:  Department major and enrollment in the Honors Program.  An examination of a significant issue affecting design, merchandising and/or textiles.  The specific topic and presentation format oral, written, graphic, model, garment prototype, computer simulation are determined by the student and faculty directing the study.  ARLD 30003 is the first of two courses required for departmental honors.  Arrangements for this directed study must be made the semester prior to enrollment in the course.

Prerequisite:  A grade of 'C' or better in ARLD 20503 and 20513.  Students will delve into the interdisciplinary factors of lighting and the human experience.  The course will draw from anthropology, psychology, neurobiology and sociology to explore how lighting is perceived and experienced by groups and individuals.  Students participate in field studies, writing assignments, research projects, and presentations.

Prerequisites: A grade of a 'C' or better in ARLD 20513 Digital Media in Lighting. This course will delve into lighting design for residential and hospitality project types. Students will conduct precedent studies to inform their understanding of daylighting and electric lighting design. The lighting design process will be explored through studio style projects including passive design and sustainable lighting strategies.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite:  Departmental major, enrollment in the Honors Program and completion of ARLD 30003.  The execution of a project or paper reflecting creative investigation or research.  Supervision by a three-member faculty committee is required.  ARLD 40003 must be completed prior to the student's final semester of undergraduate work.  May be based on subject matter explored in ARLD 30003.

Prerequisites:  A grade of 'C' or better in ARLD 20513. This course will delve into lighting design for retail and commercial project types. Students will conduct precedent studies to inform their understanding of luminaire design, daylighting, electric lighting design. The lighting design process will be explored through studio style projects.

Prerequisites:  A grade of 'C' or better in ARLD 20503 and 20513 is required.  Students will conduct independent research and a design project with specific focus into a lighting topic associated with in the built and/or natural environment.

Prerequisites:  ARLD 20513.  This course will delve into lighting design for healthcare and exterior project types. Students will conduct precedent studies to inform their understanding of lighting design for interior and exterior environments. The lighting design process will be explored through studio style projects.
Prerequisites:  Permission of Instructor.  Hours to be arranged. Special problems requiring independent research and study within a related area, or field experience in design.  (1-6 semester hours)

This is the prerequisite introductory course for all ARLE courses.  This course introduces many aspects of arts leadership and entrepreneurship, including:  mission, vision, and values, nonprofit/public organizational leadership and management, planning and evaluation, financial management, fundraising and development, managing staff and volunteers, audience development, community engagement, programming, marketing and public relations, arts entrepreneurship, and working in the arts sector.  The course also introduces students to the nonprofit sector and the current issues and trends affecting arts organizations, such as diversity, multiculturalism, inclusion, and access to the arts.

Prerequisites:  ARLE 20103.  This course covers a number of essential
components of leading complex arts organizations, including organizational dynamics and systems, balancing multiple priorities, resources, facilities and functions, developing staff and volunteers, working with unions, and coordinating projects. This course explores effective leadership practices, strategic planning,
organizational change, development and learning, human resources management and effective teams. Students develop leadership competencies and skills.

Prerequisites:  ARLE 20103.  This course covers two important areas of leading a nonprofit arts organization or managing your own artistic career.  Financial management includes establishing internal controls, risk management, accounting and financial information systems and professional standards, financial statements, budgets, endowments and restricted funds, earned income, and external reporting through audits and the 990, and tax laws for nonprofits arts organizations.  Fundraising and development include trends and motivations of donors to arts organizations, the board's fundraising responsibility, fundraising campaigns, and support systems, planned giving programs, donor relationships, grant writing and management, and fundraising ethics and professional standards.

Prerequisites:  ARLE 20103.  Arts organizations are increasing their focus on the public dimension of their operations to establish and maintain relevancy.  This public service mandate means building and serving multiple audiences and moving towards civic engagement through addressing relevant needs, building partnerships and collaborations and becoming social entrepreneurs.  Successful arts organizations understand audience learning, rights, and social needs, and they deliver exemplary customer service,.  They utilize interpretive tools, narratives and story, and multiple perspectives as they develop, manage, and evaluate a menu of program offerings and events.  The marketing and public relations section of the course covers marketing fundamentals (product, price, promotion, place), consumer behavior, marketing segmentation, branding, effective messaging and communication, and building relationships with media, businesses, government, and community.

Prerequisites:  ARLE 20103.  What opportunities are available to work in the Creative Economy?  What knowledge and skills are required to thrive in a creative economy organization or create and successfully manage your own creative business?  This course explores the economic, political, and social environment for the arts and the creative economy.  More specifically, the course covers what entrepreneurship means in arts organizations, including the production and presentation of art, utilizing creative thinking and innovation practices to solve many types of problems, and the importance and potential of technology in the creative process.  The course also explores entrepreneurship fundamentals and best practices, design thinking and group dynamics approaches, and the steps involved in creating an arts or creative venture.

Prerequisites:  This course is the CAPSTONE course for the ARLE minor.  Students should have completed the full sequence of their ARLE courses before taking this course.  In this capstone course, students apply their cumulative knowledge and skills in arts leadership and entrepreneurship to a real arts organization project on the TCU campus or in a local arts organization, for example, a strategic plan, business plan, showcase, or thesis.  Students interested in creative entrepreneurship would create a new venture or apply best practices to revitalizing an existing arts organization, on campus or in the community.  Students learn to set goals and objectives, work effectively in teams, design project work to respond to client needs, manage budgets and resources, and meet competing deadlines in a fast-paced environment mirroring real life work as an arts entrepreneur or arts leader.  They also utilize best practices in project evaluation as they assess the results of their course project(s) and their team processes.

Students complete an internship in an arts organization on campus or in the local community, 10-12 hours per week for 15 weeks, totaling 150 hours.  Students will also meet monthly with the ARLE program director.
General Transfer Credit-FAR

This introductory course presents students with a range of studio art experiences that will develop their skills in creating, analyzing, and appreciating art.  This class is designed to prepare students from all disciplines university-wide (including non-art majors) to solve problems creatively and to develop critical thinking skills that will act as a lens to understand diverse perspectives.  While the specific art media will rotate each semester, this class consistently explores Material, Process, Ideation, and Time as core components in creative practice.

Drawing as a primary art form offers a thorough exploration of the art elements: shape, value, line and texture and the spatial relationship of these art elements. Analytic drawing, perspective drawing as well as expressive approaches are employed. The keeping of a sketchbook is required.

Prerequisite: ARST 10103. Creative drawing based on visual experience and imagination. Assigned problems and experiments with a wide range of drawing materials, the use of mark-making tools and inventive exploration of media.
Study and application of basic principles of creative design.
Emphasis on use of three dimensional media, exploration of materials and introduction to some of the most widely used technical processes relative to contemporary 3-D artists.
General Transfer Credit
Prerequisites: ARST 10103, 10113. Basic painting procedures in oil and/or acrylic mediums. Introduction to techniques and material use.
Introduction to basic printmaking processes of screenprinting, relief, and intaglio (etching).  Emphasis on creative use of materials and techniques.
Introduction to materials, methods and firing techniques. Wheel thrown and hand-built ceramics.
Prerequisite: ARST 10133. Basic introduction to concept and creation of sculpture with emphasis on bronze casting, welded steel, ceramics and wood.
An introduction to the concepts, tools and techniques of new media.  Students will explore several forms of time-based media while studying related historical and contemporary artists.
Basic introduction to equipment, materials and processes of photography. Emphasis on creative use of materials and visual imagination.
Maximum 3 hours per semester. Directed individual problems to strengthen fundamental knowledge and skills required for advanced studio courses. 1-6 hours.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Studies in design research and design history.
Prerequisite: ARST 21103 (20100) or permission of instructor. Continuation of ARST 21103 (20100). (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.
Prerequisite: ARST 20143. Advanced problems in painting with emphasis on individual direction. More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21hours.

Prerequisites: Any 20000 level Art or Art History course or permission of instructor.  Examination of the historical development of Artist Books.  It will include hands-on application of visual/verbal statements and present a mixed media alternative for artists from concept through execution. More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.

Prerequisites: ARST 20163 or 20173 or 20183, or permission of instructor. Advanced printmaking techniques employed in multiple printmaking processes (relief, intaglio, silkscreen, lithography, and digital) as well as exploration of contemporary trends within the print media field.  Individual development of expression is emphasized through independent projects.  (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.)

Prerequisite: ARST 20213 or permission of instructor.  Advanced ceramic technique; clay bodies, glazes, kiln operation, raku. (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.)

Prerequisite: ARST 20213 and/or permission of instructor.  Use of ceramic materials on a greater scale as sculptural media.  Problems of handling, glazing, firing; scale as sculptural media.  (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.

This course gives students the opportunity to better understand animals and our relationships with them by producing hands-on animal imagery using a variety of media and artistic techniques, including drawing, ceramics, and sculpture.

Prerequisites: ARST 10133 and 20243.  Sculptural concepts, technical processes and translation of ideas into three dimensional situations.  (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.)

Why do many people love butterflies, but fear bats?  In 'into the Small' we will explore questions like these using multiple senses and cross-cultural perspectives, and then produce artworks in the contexts of galleries and museum exhibits to share what we find out.

Prerequisites: ARST 20503 or permission of instructor.  An advanced exploration of the concepts, tools and techniques of new media.  This course will explore the creation of digital sculptures, virtual worlds, and experimental studies with fabrication technology.

Prerequisites: ARST 20503. An advanced exploration of the concepts, tools and techniques of new media.  This course will explore the Arduino microcontroller and its ability to control our physical world.  Students will learn how to control motors, read environmental sensors, and utilize fabrication technologies such as laser engraving and 3D printing.

Prerequisite: ARST 20743, or JOUR 30233, or permission of instructor. Color photographic principles, theory, processes and practice. (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.)

Prerequisite: ARST 20743 or permission of instructor.  Techniques, methods for producing photographs under outdoor and field conditions.  Emphasis on history and practice of landscape photography, its role in the history of the American West and its position in contemporary American Art Photography.  (More than 3 hours per classes requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.)

Prerequisite: ARST 20743 or permission of instructor. Portrait photography fundamentals including lighting, equipment, social and psychological aspects of human representation, and business aspects of professional photography.

Prerequisites: ARST 20743.  This course will investigate an extensive range of non-silver, alternative, and post print manipulative processes.  (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated.)

Prerequisites: ARST 20743 and ARST 30710 or permission of instructor.  An exploration of the concepts, tools, and techniques of documentary photography.  (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.)

Prerequisites: ARST 20743 or permission of instructor.  An exploration of the concepts, tools, and techniques of studio art photography.  All photographs for this class will be staged, fabricated and directed.  (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated with permission of instructor up to 21 hours.)

Prerequisites: ARST 20743 and ARST 30710, or permission of instructor.  An introduction to the concepts tools and techniques of interactive multimedia for artists.  (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.)

Prerequisite: Junior standing in Art. The seminar will address specific professional issues such as photography of fine art, compiling slide portfolios, resume formats, exhibition preparation, exhibition venues, the role of museums and galleries, financial concerns and graduate school.

Prerequisites: Junior standing in Art or instructor permission and successful completion of ENGL 10803 and 20803.  An exploration of major approaches to art criticism and theory with emphasis on developments since 1900.

This is a hybrid course that combines theory and practice in the study of feminism and visual art making.  This course investigates the distinctive ways feminist ideas can be expressed through multiple visual art media.  Through readings, class discussions, and hands-on art projects, students will study examples of feminist art, feminist theory and criticism, and art production.  Experimentation with visual media is informed by a feminist perspective and critique.

The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite: ARGD 30003 or permission of instructor. Projects in design
research and design history. Fulfills the requirement for an Upper-Division Design
History Elective.

Prerequisites:  Junior standing.  This is a team-taught course between Environmental Science and Studio Art.  In this course students will explore the ecology and behavior of wild animals to provide insights into the types of stimuli they naturally encounter.  These insights will then be used to develop and build objects and structures that will engage and enrich the lives of animals at the Fort Worth Zoo.  Students will work in teams to study a specific species currently residing at the zoo and create objects and structures that will enhance their lives in captivity.  (Crosslisted as ARST 40553)

Prerequisites: ARST 20743 or permission of instructor.  An explorations of the concepts, tools and techniques of advanced digital photography.  (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated with instructor approval up to 21 hours.

Prerequisite: ARST 30903, or permission of instructor.  Preparation of senior qualifying exhibition.  All majors are required to exhibit selected work from their concentration.  The successful completion of this requirement is a prerequisite to graduation.

Directed individual problems beyond the scope of regular courses in the concentration. Note: No student may enroll for a Special Problems course without first discussing the nature of the intended studies and obtaining written permission of the instructor. (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated up to 21 hours.)
All majors are required to exhibit selected work from their concentration. The successful completion of this requirement is a prerequisite for graduation.
General Transfer Credit-FAR
General Transfer Credit
An experiential approach to appreciating art and music in central European countries from the period of the Enlightenment to today.

This course is an introduction to the themes and intellectual approaches that comprise the broad field of Asian Studies.  It is an interdisciplinary course that aims to introduce students primarily to the study of the peoples and cultures of East and South Asia.

This course explores the representations of culture, politics, society, and identity in a variety of films and other visual culture media (such as television, social media, literature, and music) from Asia.  During the semester students will engage a breadth of media representations pertaining to Asia to study the development of different Asian civilizations in a historical and transnational context on some of the key issues facing these countries today.

This course explores special themes in Asian Studies, including, but not limited to, literary, cinematic, social, political, economic, cultural, and international relations topics. Students analyze the course's theme on Asia in transnational contexts through class readings, presentations, discussions, and class assignments. Students will conduct research and write a final paper and/or create a final project on an approved Asian Studies topic, following the guidelines established by the instructor. This class is taught by regular or visiting faculty. Topics change each term. May be repeated for credit as topic changes.
General Transfer Credit

Two hours lecture and one two-hour laboratory period per week.  A study of biology spanning contemporary issues in the biological sciences from the cellular and molecular to the ecosystem and biosphere levels of biological organization.  Laboratory experiences are conducted in the biology computer lab.  Designed for non-science majors.
General Transfer Credit
General Transfer Credit
Microbiology Gen Transfer NSC

One laboratory period per week.  This laboratory is an inquiry-based course that provides an introduction to investigative techniques in biology and skills required for the analysis and presentation of scientific findings.  Throughout the course there will be a focus on molecules through cells.  This course is required for each student declaring a major interest in Biology and/or with an interest in pre-health programs.

Prerequisite: A senior high school course in Biology or Chemistry. This course is an introduction to the inner workings of cells, with the theme of examining the common biomolecular foundation of all living things. Topics include the basic principles of evolution, the molecular organization, structure, and function of cells, the cell cycle (including mitosis and meiosis), gene expression, metabolism, and Mendelian and molecular genetics. This course is designed for science majors.

One laboratory period per week.  This is a laboratory introduction to the diversity, evolution, anatomy and physiology of eukaryotic organism (protists, fungi, plants, and animals.)  Topics covered include the principles of evolution by natural selection , population genetics, speciation, anatomy, physiology, and taxonomy.  This course is required for each student declaring a major in Biology and/or with an interest in pre-health programs.

Prerequisite: A senior high school course in Biology or Chemistry. This course is an introduction to the workings of organisms (prokaryotes, protists, fungi, plants, and animals), with the theme of exploring the variety of solutions that have arisen in living things in response to the challenges of life. Topics include the principles of evolution, population genetics, speciation, biological systematics, reproduction, homeostasis, and physiology across various branches of life. This course is designed for science majors.

This is an inquiry-based laboratory course that provides an introduction to investigative techniques in biology and practice in the analysis and presentation of scientific findings. The topics investigated span the full scope of biology, from molecules and cells through populations and ecosystems. The course consists of one credit hour of lecture and two credit hours of lab, and is designed for science majors.
Special problems.

Prerequisite: limited to students who are majoring in Nursing (not Nursing pre-majors) and students whose first major is Kinesiology (not Kinesiology minors). Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. The structure and function of cells and tissues; the architectural plan of the human body, and the integumentary, skeletal, muscular systems and nervous systems. This course is intended for science majors that require Anatomy and Physiology as a prerequisite for application to graduate or professional school as well as Nursing, Health and Fitness, and Athletic Training majors.

Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Prerequisite: BIOL 20204 with a grade of C or better and permission of instructor. Structure and function of the nervous, circulatory, digestive, respiratory, excretory, reproductive and endocrine systems of the human body. This course is intended for science majors that require Anatomy and Physiology as a prerequisite for application to graduate or professional school as well as Nursing, Nutrition, Health and Fitness and Athletic Training majors.

Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Microorganisms and the manner in which they affect health; characteristics, growth requirements, methods of transfer, and reactions of the body toward invading organisms and the principles underlying immunity. This course is intended for Nursing, Nutrition, and Secondary Education Life Science majors or majors that require microbiology for professional school.  This course cannot be applied to the Biology major and is not intended for pre-health students applying to professional schools such as medical, dental, physician's assistant or veterinary schools.  Credit will not be given for both BIOL 20234 and 30304.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisites: BIOL 10501, 10503, 10511 and 10513.  Examination of the biological basis behind a variety of current issues in public health.  Critical analysis of these issues through lectures, class discussion and debate.

Prerequisites:  BIOL 10503 and 10513. Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week.  Study of the diversity of invertebrate animals including their morphology, physiology, development, evolution, and natural history.  Emphasis on their role as model organisms in biological and biomedical research.
Prerequisite: 10501, 10503, 10511, 10513. The economic importance of plants for food, building, material, clothing, fuel, medicine, oils, dyes and other products.

Prerequisite: BIOL 10503, 10513 and 10501 or 10523.  A general course in microbiology intended for Biology majors or pre-health students applying to professional schools such as medical, dental, physician's assistant or veterinary schools. Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week.  Credit will not be given for both BIOL 20234 and 30304.

Prerequisites:  BIOL 30403 or ENSC 30133
Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week.  An Interdisciplinary exploration of the biology, chemistry, geology, physics, and human use of the ocean and its resources.  This course is recommended for students with a major interest in the life and earth sciences.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/ENSC 30324)

Prerequisites: BIOL 10503, and 10513. Three hours lecture per week. Principles and concepts of ecology and their application to environmental biology and conservation.  Topics will include human impacts on the environment and current issues of importance to global sustainability.

Three hours lecture and one laboratory per week.  This course focuses on the form and functional significance of anatomical structures in vertebrate animals.  The objectives of the course are to introduce students to the anatomical evidence for evolution and to help students develop an understanding of vertebrate anatomy that will prepare them for graduate or medical gross anatomy courses.

Prerequisites: Biol 10513 and Biol 10511 or 10523.  Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Study of structure and functional significance of tissues, organs, and organ systems in the human body, with attention to selected disease processes.  Students will develop an understanding of human anatomy that will prepare them for graduate or medical gross anatomy courses. Credit will not be given for both BIOL 30414 and either 20204 or 20214.

Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: PSYC 10213, 10514, 10524 or its equivalent. Study of the nervous system, action systems, and sensory systems as background for the physiological bases of discrimination, motivation, emotions, and learning. (Crosslisted as BIOL/PSYC 30463.)

Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Study of the morphology, life history, physiology, ecology, evolution and socio-economic aspects of plants.  Coverage includes the cyanobacteria, fungi and algae.

Prerequisites: BIOL  10503, and 10513; CHEM 10113. Three hours lecture per week. Basic structure and function of plant and animal cells; molecular genetics of cells and organisms; mechanisms governing cell reproduction and differentiation.

Two hours lecture and one laboratory per week.  A survey of some of the diverse habitats and lifeforms on earth, with an emphasis on North American ecosystems.  Arctic tundra, forests, swamps, aquatic habitats, deserts, and mountains are considered in light of the unique adaptations required for associated fauna and flora, and especially, some of the challenges they face in the modern world.  The course is designed for students with broad interests in science, especially environmental science and education majors and is also suitable for non-science majors.  This course cannot be applied toward the biology course requirements for a biology major.

Two hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Characteristics of the major groups and families of flowering plants. Basic history and general principles of taxonomy and fundamental concepts of phylogeny and plant evolution. Identification of plants represented in the local flora.

Prerequisites:  BIOL 10503 or 10513.  In this course, human ecto- and endo-parasites will be discussed along with their associated diseases.  Students will gain knowledge of parasite life cycle, molecular mechanisms of entry, mechanisms of immune evasion and current and potential therapies.  Public health strategies for control and elimination of parasitic diseases will also be explored.

Prerequisites: PHYS 20484 or 20485 or 10164.  An introduction to image formation for molecular and medical applications.  This course covers the fundamentals of optic, x-ray and MRI, image creation, detectors, basics of image processing, quantitative analysis and a variety of applications in biophysics and in medicine.  Includes off-campus lab work.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/PHYS 30843.)

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Honors Seminar.  May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.

Prerequisites: BIOL 30603. This 0.5-hour course focuses on a variety of topics relevant to students who are interested in careers in the health professions. The course may be repeated.  At most one hour may be applied to the Biology major or minor.
Prerequisites: BIOL 30603.  Three hours lecture per week. Survey course in the study of mechanisms of inheritance with particular emphasis on molecular genetics.

Prerequisites:  BIOL 30603.  A one credit hour laboratory course (one laboratory period a week). After completion of the course the student will develop an understanding of concepts and techniques currently in use in molecular biology and biotech research laboratories and will learn how to use basic bioinformatics tools to analyze DNA sequences.

Prerequisites: BIOL  30603; CHEM 30123 (or concurrent enrollment) or permission of instructor.  A study of the molecular mechanisms of human disease with an emphasis on the role of intracellular signaling events on the manifestation of disease, gene expression/regulation, the structure and function of macromolecules, cell growth and differentiation, and biotechnology based solutions to treatment.
Two three-hour laboratories plus associated lectures each week.  Prerequisites: BIOL 30603 and 40123.  Experiments that illustrate the basic principles of transmission and molecular genetics.

Prerequisites: BIOL 10501, 10503, 10511, 10513, 30403, and 30603.  Genetics plays an important and diverse role in the preservation of biological diversity.  This course consists of two one-hour lectures and one three-hour laboratory each week and covers genetic theory and methods that are utilized in modern conservation efforts.  Laboratory exercises focus on 1) the practical aspects of DNA extraction methods, molecular markers, PCR, sequencing, and capillary electrophoresis, and 2) analyzing the resulting genetic data.

Prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology.  This course consists of two one-hour lectures and one three-hour laboratory each week.  Lectures cover the evolution, anatomy and physiology, life histories, behaviors, and conservation of birds.  The laboratory portion of the course includes identifying birds with molecular methods and field trips to identify common species of Texas birds.  Five Saturday morning field trips are required.

Prerequisites: six semester hours in Biology.  Two hour lectures and two hours of laboratory per week.  This course introduces advanced undergraduate students to mammals.  Lectures will examine the major topics of mammalian biology, including the evolutionary history, classification, adaptations, ecology, and natural history of mammals.  Field techniques for the study of mammalian biodiversity and abundance will also be covered in this course.  Field trips will be required. (Crosslisted as BIOL/ENSC 40173.)

Prerequisites:  BIOL 30603 and BIOL 30403 OR Instructor Permission.  This course critically engages the historical eugenics movement in the United States and its precursors in the broader Western scientific tradition with attention to current and future advancements in biology. Students will employ a combination of scientific and ethical analysis to interrogate social/political and biological claims about inherited traits and race that were dominant in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.  Students will further analyze contemporary advancements in biology while applying ethical lessons from the past.
Prerequisite: BIOL 30603 or permission of the instructor. Two hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Study of basic tissues of the vertebrate body and how they differentiate.

Prerequisite: BIOL 30603 or permission of the instructor.  Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week.  An introduction to developmental biology and embryology.  Modern molecular and genetic techniques will be combined with classic anatomical embryology.

Prerequisites:  C- or better in BIOL 30603, or permission of instructor. Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. The immune system; characteristics of antigens; antibodies and their reactions; cellular and humoral aspects of immunity; immune disorders.

Prerequisite: BIOL 30304 or BIOL 40254.  This lecture-based course features current research in Immunology that focuses on how manipulations of the innate or adaptive immune system can modulate disease states. This includes how microbes overcome immune defenses, failures in immune system function and
how the immune system can be therapeutically modified to treat disease.

Prerequisite:  BIOL 40123.  This class will consist of two hours of lecture and one laboratory per week.  The course focuses on the ways in which information at the genome level has become integral to Biology.  The labs are designed to give students hands on experience analyzing genomic data to ask and answer specific questions.  Contemporary primary literature will be discussed.

Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.  This course focuses on advanced topics in medical microbiology including disease mechanisms of major human pathogens, the host response, and antibiotic development and resistance.  Scientific approaches used to investigate these topics are emphasized through reading and discussion of the primary literature.
Prerequisite: BIOL 30403 or permission of instructor. Three hours lecture per week. An ecological approach to the study of the distribution of plant and animal communities.

Prerequisite: Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve.  Students serve as laboratory instructors of one section per week in introductory-level biology courses.  Students receive 1 credit for serving as laboratory instructors for one section per week and one additional credit for each three hours of additional duties per week including laboratory staff meetings.  May be repeated once.

Prerequisite: Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve.  Students receive one credit hour for serving as laboratory instructors of one section per week and one additional credit hour for each three hours of additional duties per week including laboratory staff meetings.  This course is intended only for undergraduate Teaching Assistants in courses above the freshman level.  Not to exceed six hours credit on the major and eight hours credit total.

Prerequisite: Six semester hours in Biology.  Two hour lectures and a three hour laboratory each week.  This discussion-oriented course introduces advanced undergraduate students to the general principles of wildlife ecology and how those principles can be applied to wildlife management and conservation.  The objectives of this course are 1) to provide an introduction to the major concepts of Wildlife Ecology and Management and 2) to allow you to learn the application of the scientific method to ecological problems.  Laboratory exercises are required.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/ENSC 40353)

Prerequisites: BIOL 30603 with a C or better or permission of instructor. Basic functions of the major mammalian systems will be studied in terms of physical and chemical principles and system interactions.

Prerequisites: BIOL 40403.  This course focuses on the underlying principles of toxicology including dose-response curves, routes of contaminant exposure, contaminant fate in the environment and in organisms, and xenobiotic metabolism.  Discussions of both historical and contemporary primary literature will be used to explore the specific effects of contaminants on various physiological systems.

Prerequisite: BIOL 40403.  Two hours of lecture and one laboratory period per week.  The course will focus on the structure and function of hormone signaling systems in vertebrate organisms.  Contemporary primary literature will be discussed and the laboratory will expose students to the experimental design and methods utilized in modern endocrinology research.

Prerequisites:  CHEM 30123 and C- or better in BIOL 30603, or permission of instructor.  Three hours of lecture per week.  The structures, properties, and functions of biological molecules (proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates), with emphasis on analysis techniques and relation to physiology.

Prerequisites:  BIOL 40513 or BIOL/CHEM 50133 or equivalent course.  Two hours of lecture and two hours of laboratory per week.  Students will learn structural biology techniques important for designing pharmaceuticals and design a drug to their favorite protein target.  Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 40523.

Prerequisites: BIOL 30603 or permission of instructor. Three hours lecture per week.  Survey of viruses, molecular biology of virus life cycles, viral pathogenesis and gene therapy using viral vectors.

Prerequisites:  6 credit hours of Biology or equivalent.  The course examines selected cultures in an international setting.  Social and scientific factors are related to health beliefs and practices and health care delivery systems of the country visited and examined.  Critical analysis of selected topics will be accomplished.  Usually taught in summer abroad program.  (Cross-listed as BIOL 40703/NURS 30063/ENSC 40203)

Prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor. This one to four credit, lecture-only course will deal with a specific topic in Biology that is appropriate for Biology majors.

Prerequisites:  BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor.  This one to four credit lecture with integrated lab course will deal with a specific topic in Biology that is appropriate for Biology majors. This course can be repeated. This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. or B.A. degree in biology.

Prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor. This one or two credit lab course will deal with a specific topic in Biology that is appropriate for Biology majors. This course can be repeated. This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. or B.A. degree in biology.

Prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor.  This one to four credit, lecture-only course will deal with a specific topic in Biology that is appropriate for Biology majors.

Field and laboratory research experiences for advanced students. Nine clock hours per week are required total 135 hours per semester. Upon completion of an independent research project, the results will be written in a format suitable for publication in the scientific literature. A student may receive credit for this course only one time. Credit will not be given for both BIOL 40803 and BIOL 40003 for the same project.  This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. degree in biology.

Prerequisites:  BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor.  This one to four credit lecture with integrated lab course will deal with a specific topic in Biology that is appropriate for Biology majors. This course can be repeated. This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. or B.A. degree in biology.

Prerequisite: Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve. Students serve as laboratory instructors of one section per week in introductory-level biology courses. Students receive 1 credit for serving as laboratory instructors for one section per week and one additional credit for each three hours of additional duties per week including laboratory staff meetings. May be repeated once.

Prerequisite: Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve.  Students receive one credit hour for serving as laboratory instructors of one section per week and one additional credit hour for each three hours of additional duties per week including laboratory staff meetings.  This course is intended only for undergraduate Teaching Assistants in courses above the freshman level.  Not to exceed six hours credit on the major and eight hours credit total.

Field and laboratory problems for advanced students. Three clock hours per week of laboratory and/or field work are required for each semester hour of credit, for up to three semester hours credit in any given semester.  This course can be repeated or taken in combination with 40803 or 40033.  This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. degree in biology.

Field and laboratory research experiences for advanced students. Nine clock hours per week are required total 135 hours per semester. Upon completion of an independent research project, the results will be written in a format suitable for publication in the scientific literature. A student may receive credit for this course only one time. Credit will not be given for both BIOL 40903 and BIOL 40933 for the same project. This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. degree in biology.

Prerequisites:  Instructor permission.  This course focuses on current scientific research in biology including discussions of primary literature and presentations of active research projects.  This course may be repeated.  May only be taken P/NC.  This course cannot be applied toward the course requirements for the biology major or minor.

This course is only for students in the Honors College. Field and laboratory research experiences for advanced students. Nine clock hours per week are required for a total of 135 hours. The results will be written in the form of a senior honors research thesis to be presented to the Honors College. A student may receive credit for this course only one time. Credit will not be given for both 40933 and 40903 for the same project. This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. degree in biology.

Prerequisites:  Senior standing as a biology major with an Intent to Graduate on file in the Dean's Office.  One class session.  Graduating seniors enrolled in this course will complete the exit exam required of biology majors.  May only be taken P/NC.

Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: BIOL 30403 or permission of instructor. Concepts, principles, and mechanisms of the function of terrestrial ecosystems, including ecophysiology of component species, nutrient cycling, energy flow, ecosystem stability and global ecology.

Prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and 30603 or permission of instructor.  Two hours lecture and two hours of computer lab per week.  Students will gain knowledge and understanding of how statistical methods are applied to biological research.  The course will emphasize hypothesis testing, study design, and the concepts, application, and interpretation of statistical results.  Basic probability theory, parametric statistics, correlation, regression, analysis of variance, and non-parametric statistics will be introduced.

Prerequisite: CHEM 30133 and 40123 or permission of instructor. Three hours lecture per week. A general survey of structure and function of biologically important compounds with methods of analysis. (Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 50133.)

Prerequisite: BIOL/CHEM 50133. Biosynthesis, replication of DNA, synthesis and processing of RNA and proteins, and special topics e.g. brain and muscle functions, hormones and signal transduction, cancer, development, etc.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 50143.)

Three hours lecture per week.  Prerequisites: BIOL/CHEM 50143, or permission of instructor.  Molecular mechanism of drug actions, and methods of drug design, discovery and development.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 50153.)

Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: BIOL 10501, 10503 10511 and 10513. Concepts and principles of organic evolution.  Topics include natural selection, adaptation, quantitative genetics, sexual selection, kin selection, life history characters, speciation, and phylogeny.

Prerequisites:  BIOL 30603 and 40123 with a C or better in each or permission of instructor.  This course introduces the theory of evolution and its real-world applications to the practice of medicine.  Concepts of survival and reproduction defining evolutionary fitness, co-evolution, competition, natural selection, bottleneck effects, adaptation and exaptation will be introduced and applied in the context of managing and treating infectious and non-infectious human and animal diseases.  These concepts will be applied beyond individual-level medicine to population-level public health.

Prerequisites: permission of instructor.  The current literature associated with the neurobiology of aging, modern research techniques and recent developments in neuroscience and aging research are discussed.  This is a participation course in which advanced undergraduate and graduate students will present manuscripts, explain research hypotheses and methodologies and explain results.  Open discussion of these papers will include faculty from Biology and Psychology.  Topics presented will differ by semester.  The course may be repeated three times (taken a maximum of four semesters in all.)  (Crosslisted as BIOL/PSYC 50401.)

Prerequisite: Graduate or senior standing or permission of instructor. The fundamentals of functional neuroanatomy and neurophysiology with an emphasis on experimental and theoretical analysis of the basic brain behavior relationships.   (Crosslisted as BIOL/PSYC 50463.)
Two four-hour laboratory periods per week. Prerequisite: CHEM 50143 or concurrent registration.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 50502)

Prerequisite: BIOL 30403 or permission of instructor. Two hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Study of the physical, chemical and biological factors affecting the ecology of lakes, ponds and streams.

Prerequisite: Six semester hours in Biology; travel costs are exclusive of tuition.   This course provides an introduction to the marine animals, plants, and ecosystems of the New World tropics.  Lecture topics will include tropical oceanography and ecosystems, evolutionary patterns in the tropics, island biogeography, and conservation of marine biodiversity.  The field experience will expose students to coastal marine ecosystems (coral reefs, mangroves, beaches, and seagrass beds).  Two hours lecture per week, one week of field work in the tropics.

Two hours lecture per week, one week of field work in the tropics and a terminal project. Prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology; travel costs are exclusive of tuition; permission of instructors. This course provides an introduction to the animals, plants, and ecosystems of the New World tropics.  Lecture topics will include tropical climate and ecosystems, evolutionary patterns in the tropics, and conservation of biodiversity.  The field experience will expose students to coastal ecosystems (coral reefs, mangroves, and seagrass beds) as well as tropical, lowland rainforest.

1. The primary goal is to acquaint the student with the preparation and presentation (oral and/or written) of scientific information from the biological literature. May be repeated for credit with different topics to a maximum of 3 times (one semester hour per topic). 2. Acquainting the student with the preparation and presentation (oral and/or written) of scientific information from the biological literature. May be repeated for credit with different topics to a maximum of 3 times. (One semester hour per topic.)

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This is a capstone course for the minor, and includes readings in British and colonial/postcolonial studies and an independent project.  The independent project is pursued in consultation with the program director, and aims to reflect on the student's work in the minor, to synthesize the skills developed through the student's coursework, and to consider how they might be applied after graduation.  Projects may include: an original creative performance; a scientific investigation; a portfolio of critical writing; or a U.S.-based internship with an employer with substantial interests in Britain or the former colonies.  All projects also require a journal documenting and reflecting on the student's progress.

Washington Center or at the TCU in London Program.  Full-time internships with a public or private agency in Washington, D.C. or in London, England, offered either through the Washington Center or through the TCU in London Program.  The internship will allow students to integrate theory and practice in a supervised professional setting, up to 12 semester hours credit. (Offered as BRST or POSC credit.)

3-day or 4-day per week interns with public or private agencies in London, England, offered through the TCU in London Program.  Offered during the fall and spring terms, these internships accommodate students' long-term professional objectives.  Internships are offered for either 9 or 12 semester hours credit.  Most of the London interns also take one or two classroom courses while in London.  (Offered either for BRST or POSC credit.)

Prerequisites:  Concurrent enrollment in BUSI 10153.  This course is designed to assist students in discovering the wide range of professional opportunities ahead of them.  Students will engage in powerful self-assessments, use a variety of skills to continuously expand their opportunity spectrums, learn how to overcome obstacles, conduct effective research, and also experience a first-hand taste of different potential careers.

Prerequisites:  Must be a Pre-Business major.Business is an increasingly impactful participant in our lives.  Business affects society and society affects business.  This course is designed to provide business majors a broad perspective on what business is, how it fits into the rest of society, and how the study of business connects with the rest of their learning as a liberally educated student at TCU.  In the practice of business, there are seldom right answers to important questions.  The ability to identify alternative approaches and to find, explain, and defend the best one is a key skill for the study and practice of business.  This course focuses on developing these critical thinking skills.
General Transfer Credit

Prerequisites: The class is open to all students admitted to the Neeley School of Business.  Students in their First Year enroll in their second semester on campus, or a subsequent semester; transfer students admitted to Neeley may enroll in their first semester on campus, or a subsequent semester.  This course provides students seeking a business major with direction and guidance regarding: 1) the major and career selection and exploration process; 2) organizing their internship search; and 3) developing a professional portfolio that will equip them with skills and resources to discover and explore professional opportunities that align with their interests, values, and skills. Students will engage with recruiters, alumni, and Neeley students across a variety of industries and majors to learn about career paths, recruiting timelines, and industry trends. Students will familiarize themselves with Neeley's resources and determine a personalized plan for career exploration and development.
Prerequisite:  Must be a business major.  Special Topics in Business.  (1-6 semester hours)  This course may be repeated for credit.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite:  Must be a business major.  This course focuses on ethical global business and developing a global mindset from an intellectual, psychological and social perspective.  Topics include the global mindset framework, unique characteristics of the global trade environment, globalization of ethical decision making, the role of culture in global business, and responsible, financial and regulatory implications for global business.  The student will engage in a cross cultural experience including ethical reflection.

A general, semi-technical orientation of the Oil, Gas and Power industries including the origins and overview of the O&G industry, explanation of exploration and production (E&P) processes, logistics, value chain, and the marketing of petroleum, natural gas, and power.  Class material will be presented by textbook and guest lecturers.

3 hours. Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, must be a Business major.  This course and MANA 30313 cannot both be taken for credit.  This course is designed to help students learn what leadership is and how to be a more effective leader of others.  Emphasis in this course is on leading self, including being proactive, setting goals and priorities, and self-awareness of values and strengths and weaknesses as a basis for developing a personalized vision for the kind of leader you want to become.

3 hours. Prerequisite: BUSI 30833 with a grade of at least C for students in the BNSF Neeley Leadership Program, Sophomore standing, and must be a Business major.  This course is designed to help students learn what it takes to effectively lead others one-on-one or in small groups.  Emphasis is placed on interpersonal behaviors and skills, including listening, asking questions, feedback giving and receiving, coaching, building trust, followership, and persuasion and communication.
Student is studying away this semester with a Partner Program.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Variable credit hours 1-3. Course may only be taken for a maximum of three credit hours.  Pass/No Credit grade type only.   Prerequisites: Must be a declared Business major or Finance or Accounting minor, and permission of instructor.  Students gain practical exposure to business through participation in an internship in a business or community organization.  Emphasis is placed on the development of applied skills in one or more of the business disciplines.  Students learn about organizational realities and work demands.

Prerequisites: Must be a declared Business major or Finance or Accounting minor, and permission of instructor.   Students gain practical exposure to business through participation in an internship in a business or community organization. Emphasis is placed on the development of applied skills in one or more of the business disciplines. Students learn about organizational realities and work demands.
1 credit hour. Course may be repeated 3 times to receive a maximum of 3 credit hours. Pass/No Credit grade type only.

Prerequisites:  Must be a declared business major. This one-credit course will provide direction and instructional tools for students to complete a departmental honors project in their major department. The goal of the course is to develop a project statement (introduction, literature review, research questions/hypothesis, methodology), and prepare for data collection if applicable.

Prerequisites:  Must be a Junior or a Senior standing.  An introduction to basic financial literacy.  This course will prepare students for lifelong financial success after college by providing them with a foundational knowledge in a number of key topics including: how to create a budget, to buy or lease a car, creating an emergency fund, investment fundamentals, importance of credit scores and much more.

The course will cover, physical and financial trading of energy commodities ("cash" market, NYMEX contracts, swaps, options, and hedging), technical analysis and, risk control. Addresses the following resource/product groups oil, natural gas, gasoline, heating oil, LNG, electricity and, time permitting, emissions credits. While focused on the North American energy landscape, discussions of international oil and gas markets will be incorporated where appropriate. Students will also actively trade a financial energy derivatives "book" utilizing an online trading simulator.

A semi-technical study of the electric utility industry, which focuses on traditional and alternative/renewable sources, industry organization, logistics & value chain, power demand management, conservation, and energy efficiency. Demand response methods and programs as well as, smart grids will also be covered.

Principles and practices of doing business in the renewable energy and alternative fuels sectors. Investigates the feasibility and economics of competing energy sources and technologies and considers their contribution to a total system approach to energy business. Includes concepts of innovation, relevant business models, the use of government incentives, tax credits, regulatory mandates, as well as financing, distribution, and infrastructure challenges and evolving markets and consumer demand.

3 hours.  Prerequisites: Enrolled in the BNSF Neeley Leadership Program, and MANA 40213 with at least a grade of C.  This course is designed to help students learn what it takes to successfully lead change efforts and plan and implement projects that promote the common good.  As such, it will cover topics such as overcoming complacency, creating and communicating new direction, developing support for initiatives, communicating effectively about an initiative, and dealing with resistance, among others.  Students in this course are expected to use what they've learned in prior leadership courses to lead a field-based project to a successful completion.  Class sessions will help students relate their field experience to topic coverage in this course as well as to other courses in the Neeley Leadership Program.

Prerequisite: BUSI 40843 with a grade of at least C for students in the BNSF Neeley Leadership Program.  For others, any two of the following with a grade of at least C, BUSI 30833, BUSI 30843, MANA 40213, MANA 40343.  This course is designed to help students understand the complexity of the contexts in which leadership occurs.    Students will gain a better understanding of: 1) the nature of complexity in business and social systems, 2) the implications of complexity for how organizations must think differently about leadership and followership (e.g., regarding organization structure, culture, power and communication), and 3) how each student personally needs to lead and follow in organizational contexts to be successful as they transition into and advance in their careers.
Prerequisite:  Must be a declared business major.  Special Problems in Business.  (1-6 semester hours)  This course may be repeated for credit.
General Transfer Credit

This course is designed to provide an introduction to trauma-informed care and interventions.  Students will learn about the impact of trauma, the pillars of trauma-informed care and current evidence based, trauma-informed interventions such as Trust-Based Relational Intervention.

This course is designed to increase awareness about children's issues in the global community both historically and currently.  It will focus on children's issues as well as intervention efforts across the globe.  Along with class lectures, readings, and video supplements, students will be expected to participate in class discussions and presentations about current global issues.  This course is designed to build insight and competency in students who desire to work with children in their future careers.

Prerequisites:  30 cumulative hours of coursework is required.  A developmental class is recommended.  In this course, history, theory and neuroscience of play are examined.  Play as it relates to physical, social, cognitive, language and emotional development is explored in children birth through adolescence.  The impact of culture, gender, and technology on children's play is explored.  Special attention is given to play observations, assessment through play, and therapeutic play.

Prerequisites:  PSYC 10213 and MATH 10043.  The purpose of this course is to familiarize students with the basics of developmental research and evaluation. This class will cover topics such as research versus evaluation, evaluation, research design, research projects start to finish, data and analysis, and reporting findings and publications.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course is designed to prepare students with professional competencies and knowledge in working with children and families.  The course will be taught as a seminar style course with visiting professionals and professors teaching on topics such as: Crisis Prevention Intervention (CPI), Child CPR, Child Abuse Prevention and Reporting, Cultural Competencies, Communication Skills, Professional Ethics, Therapeutic Boundaries.  At the end of the course, students will have skills and preparation for a variety of careers with children.

Prerequisites: NURS 10303 or PSYC 30313 or 40433.  This child life course will focus on children in the healthcare environment.  It will include study in the following areas pertaining to child life specialists; documentation; scope of practice; impact of illness, injury, and health care of patients and families; family-centered care; therapeutic play; and preparing children for healthcare encounters and life-changing events.

Prerequisites: PSYC/CHDV 50433 and PSYC/CHDV 50443.  This experiential course provides advanced opportunities to work with children through internship positions.  Service environments will provide experiential learning through which the student will utilize their knowledge of child development.  Students can obtain their own positions (e.g., women shelter volunteer; child life specialist practicum) or can take part in internships facilitated by the instructor.  Students complete 100 hours at the internship site.  Students also attend a weekly one-hour seminar during the semester to discuss their experiences with peers and faculty and learn about working in helping professions.

This course is designed to explore historical and contemporary theories related to family functioning and to analyze the impact of varying demographics, stressors, and transitions on family dynamics. Theories will be presented in class and applied to diverse family systems within cultural and societal contexts. Emphasis will be placed on non-traditional family systems and the varied impact of stressors on different types of family systems.

Prerequisites: must be a CHDV major and have senior standing.  This course is designed for seniors to promote an integrated understanding of the discipline and to examine the significance of research and policy in child development.  The emphasis is on assisting the student in developing the ability to critically evaluate methods, problems and findings of research in the field of child development and to evaluate contrasting views of major issues within the discipline.

Prerequisite: Junior standing. This course is the first of a two-part series of multidisciplinary courses which examine children who have experienced complex developmental trauma, including outcomes, assessments, and interventions through a study of peer-reviewed articles and evidence-based interventions, including Trust-Based Relational Intervention (TBRI). TBRI is an attachment based, trauma-informed intervention designed to meet the complex needs of children through connecting, empowering, and correcting. Emphasis in this course will be attachment theory and the development of healthy relationships. Completing this course is recommended to work at The Hope Connection 2.0 therapeutic camp. (Crosslisted as CHDV/PSYC 50433.)

Prerequisites: CHDV 50433 and junior standing.  This course is the second of a two-part series of multidisciplinary courses which examine children who have experienced complex developmental trauma.  Emphasis in Trauma and Behavior is on understanding the effects of trauma on the body, brain, and behavior, as well as demonstrating trauma-informed intervention strategies and skills. Completing this course is recommended to work at The Hope Connection 2.0 therapeutic camp.

Prerequisite: Junior standing.  This course is designed to present an integrated and comprehensive overview of numerous issues in child development as well as treatments/solutions for those issues.  This diverse array of developmental problems will be presented in a series of case-studies by professors from several departments as well as by community professionals who specialize in children's issues.  This course is a requirement for the Child Development Minor as well as an elective course in Psychology.  (Crosslisted as CHDV/PSYC 50533.)

Prerequisites:   CHDV 50433 and 50443.  This course is designed to be an intensive study in putting Trust-Based Relational Intervention (TBRI) into practice within a professional setting. Upon successful completion of the course (80% or above) students will earn the title and status of TBRI Practitioner.
General Transfer Credit-NSC

Prerequisites:  Major in engineering.  Selected topics from General Chemistry designed to provide mastery of chemistry concepts needed for success in undergraduate engineering courses. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 10013 and CHEM 10113.

Three lecture hours per week.  Introduction to chemical principles and their application: stoichiometry, solutions, oxidation-reduction, thermochemistry,
atomic structure, bonding theories, molecular geometries, gases/liquids/solids, intermolecular forces of attraction. Emphasis on problem-solving and visualizing matter at the particulate level. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 10013 and CHEM 10113.
One lecture and one 3-hour laboratory session per week. Prerequisites: CHEM 10113 and prior or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 10123.

Prerequisite:  CHEM 10113 with a grade of C- or better.  Three lecture hours per week.  Introduction to chemical principles and their application: solutions, chemical
equilibria (gas, acid/base, solubility), kinetics, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, simple organic nomenclature, transition-metal coordination compounds. Emphasis on problem-solving and visualizing matter at the particulate level.

Prerequisite:  CHEM 10113 with a grade of C- or better.  Three hours lecture, one 3-hour laboratory, and one 1-hour lab lecture per week.  The second of a two-semester sequence in introductory chemistry.  Selected concepts regarding chemical equilibria, kinetics, electrochemistry, and introductory organic chemistry.
General Transfer Credit

This interdisciplinary course, which includes two hours of lecture and one (two hour) laboratory period per week, explores the role of chemistry in artistic expression and cultural practices throughout history. Students will examine the chemical processes involved in various art forms, materials, and techniques involved in the production and preservation of art. Through lectures and hands-on labs, students will investigate topics like color formation, the chemistry of paint mediums, the effects of the environment on artwork and the chemistry of body art and textiles This course is designed for non-science majors.

Three lecture hours per week.  Introduction to basic chemical principles: atomic & molecular structure, light, bonding, nomenclature, stoichiometry, oxidation-reduction, solutions, gases/liquids/solids, intermolecular forces, and thermochemistry.  Emphasis on problem-solving and practical applications from industry, the earth, and living organisms.  This course serves as a prerequisite for CHEM 10225, but does not qualify as a prerequisite for CHEM 10123.

Prerequisite: CHEM 10213 or CHEM 10113. Three lecture hours per week plus 3 hours of integrated lab & 1 hour of lab lecture.  Introduction to basic chemical principles: solutions, chemical equilibria (gas, acid/base, solubility), kinetics, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, and radiochemistry.  Emphasis on problem-solving and practical applications from industry, the earth, and living organisms.
General Transfer Credit

Prerequisites: CHEM 10113, and prior or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 10123.  One hour lecture and two laboratory periods per week.  Exposure to techniques, theory, and laboratory practice of quantitative chemical analysis, focusing on gravimetric and volumetric analysis.  Students will also gain an introductory understanding of instrumental methods of chemical analysis.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisites:  CHEM 10122 or 20123.  This course aims to cultivate a robust safety culture, aligning with the accreditation standards set by the American Chemical Society (ACS). As safety training becomes a cornerstone of ACS certification, this course empowers students with essential knowledge and skills to navigate laboratory environments safely and responsibly. Designed to be activities-based, the course utilizes hands-on experience to emphasize laboratory safety, allowing students to apply theoretical knowledge in practical settings. Participants will delve into the RAMP framework --Recognize, Assess, Minimize, and Prepare --drawing from the guidelines outlined in Laboratory Safety for Chemistry Students (Hill & Finster, 2010).

One hour of lecture per week and seven 4-hour laboratory periods during the semester.  Prerequisite: CHEM 10122 or 20123 with a grade of C- or better and prior or concurrent registration in CHEM 30123.  Techniques of purification, characterization, and synthesis of organic compounds.
Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: CHEM 10123 with a grade of C- or better.  A survey of the classes of organic compounds with regard to nomenclature, structure, and reactions.
Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: CHEM 30123 with a grade of C- or better. Stereochemistry, organic reaction mechanisms, and synthesis of organic compounds.

Two one-hour lectures and one 4-hour laboratory per week. Prerequisite: CHEM 30121 with a grade of C- or better and 30133 or concurrent registration. Chemical and instrumental means of identifying unknown organic substances.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

A project in chemical research carried out under the direction of a member of the chemistry faculty and designed to partially fulfill the requirements for Departmental Honors in Chemistry. Hours arranged.

A project in chemical research carried out under the direction of a member of the chemistry faculty and designed to partially fulfill the requirements for Departmental Honors in Chemistry. Hours arranged.

The chemical literature, modern research techniques and recent developments in chemistry are discussed.  This is a capstone course to be taken by Chemistry and Biochemistry majors in the fall semester of their senior year.

Prerequisite: Prior or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 40123.  Alternating weeks of 1-hour laboratory lecture and 4-hour laboratory experiment.  Laboratory experiments designed to convey fundamental principles of physical chemistry, with emphasis on chemical equilibrium in solution.

Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: CHEM 10125 or 10122-10123 or 10123- 20123, prior or concurrent enrollment in MATH 10524. Studies of the fundamental physical principles relating to the field of chemistry, with an emphasis on thermodynamics and electrochemistry.

Prerequisites: Prior or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 40133.   Alternating weeks of 1-hour laboratory lecture and 4-hour laboratory experiment. Laboratory experiments designed to convey fundamental principles of physical chemistry, with emphasis on polymers and computational methods.

Three hours lecture per week.  Prerequisites: CHEM 40123, MATH 20524, PHYS 20484 or PHYS 10164 (or concurrent enrollment).  Continuation of studies of the fundamental physical principles relating to the field of chemistry, with an emphasis on quantum chemistry, spectroscopy, and kinetics.
