A course designed for students whose first language is other than English; student should have an advanced level of ability to write in English.  The course fosters improvement of composition skills by writing ethnography (or the writing of American academic culture particularly).  Concurrent enrollment is expected in one of the following course:  ENGL 10803 Introductory Composition: Writing from Sources; ENGL 10833 Comp: Freshman Seminar; or ENGL 20803 Intermediate composition: Writing within communities. The TWE is required as a final exam.
General Transfer Credit
Prerequisite: Merchandising major or permission of chair.  Comprehensive introduction to the terminology, processes, practices, and interrelationships involved in the fashion industry.
Topics may vary each time it is offered.

Prerequisites: Must be a Merchandising major, PSYC 10213 or SOCI 20213, and a grade of 'C' or better in FAME 10243.  Exploration of the external and internalfactors influencing global fashion consumers and their behaviors.  Analysis of the motivation and consumer decision making process for fashion consumers in the global environment.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major.  Integrated lecture and lab.  A comprehensive introduction to terminology and processes of producing fibers, yarns, and fabrics. Appropriate use of textiles in products and overview of sustainable practices.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major; DSGN 10153 a grade of C or better in FAME 10243 and 20253; and a grade of C or better in FAME 20273 or concurrent enrollment.  Development of illustration skills to produce technical flats of garments, concept development, presentation skills, basic fashion illustration and the application of design principles and elements.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major; a grade of C or better in FAME 10243 and 20253.  Integrated lecture and lab.  Development of basic apparel constructions skills.  Understanding of proper fit and quality construction of apparel.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major.  Examination of branding and strategic marketing principles for traditional and emerging digital media. Explore digital merchandising and marketing strategies for the fashion industry.
Prerequisites: Declared merchandising major.  The study of selected topics in Design and Merchandising.  These topics will vary and may be repeated for credit with different course material.
Student is studying abroad this semester with a Partner Program.

Prerequisite:  Departmental major and enrollment in the Honors Program.  An examination of a significant issue affecting design, merchandising and/or textiles.  The specific topic and presentation format oral, written, graphic, model, garment prototype, computer simulation are determined by the student and faculty directing the study.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major, and a grade of C or better in FAME 20273. The study of the interrelationship of costume with economic, political and technological environments through a comparison study of civilizations from ancient times through to present day.

Prerequisites: English 20803.  .An overview of sustainability issues in textile and apparel.  The objective of this course is to provide an understanding of the role and impact of textile and apparel supply chain/industry on the global economy, environment, and society.  Students are encouraged to re-think and re-assess their position, values, biases of their own consumer identity and consumer practices.

Prerequisite:  Merchandising major, MS Excel Certification, TCU Core Math requirement,  and a 'C' or better in FAME 20273.   An analysis of the retail math concepts and tools required for planning, buying and selling merchandise.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major; a grade of C or better in FAME 20253, 20263, and 20273. Use of current industry software applications to develop textile designs, technical flat illustrations and presentation skills.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major, a grade of 'C' or better in FAME 20253 and 20273.  The creative and technical processes used for design and development of apparel products including industry techniques for pattern development, style and fit analysis, and advanced construction methods for assembly and production.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major; a grade of C or better in FAME 20263 and   20273. Study in careers as a pre-requisite to completion of the official internship. Emphasis is on self assessment, career research and resources, and the development of career search tools including resume writing, cover letter writing, interviewing, leadership concepts, effective communication skills, writing skills and advancement techniques.

Prerequisite: Merchandising major, CORE math, and a grade of C or better in FAME 30273 or concurrent enrollment. Process of product development including research, line development, materials selection, fabric and style specifications, costing, and merchandising. Identifying stitch and seam classifications, and discussion of production techniques and quality considerations.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite:  Departmental major, enrollment in the Honors Program and completion of FAME 30003.  The execution of a project or paper reflecting creative investigation or research.  Supervision by a three-member faculty committee is required.  FAME 40003 must be completed prior to the student's final semester of undergraduate work.  May be based on subject matter explored in FAME 30003.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major, a C or better in FAME 30253, 30263 or 30293,  and ENGL 20803.  Introduction to the opportunities, risks and management problems involved in establishing and operating new enterprises related to the major.  Emphasis is on business plan development.
One week study tour of New York City's textile, apparel and merchandising industries accompanied by two weeks of on-campus study.

Prerequisite: Merchandising major, ENGL 20803, and a C or better in FAME 20243 and 30233.  Exploration of methods used to investigate, develop insights into, and formulate statements about clothing and appearance behavior.  Emphasis on the development of critical thinking and writing skills.

Prerequisites: Declared merchandising major and permission of department.  The study of selected topics in Merchandising.  These topics will vary and may be repeated for credit with different course material.

Prerequisites: Merchandising major, ECON 10223 or 10233, and a C or better in FAME 30292 and 30293.  A comprehensive study and evaluation of the global textile and apparel supply chain including socio-cultural, economic, political and technological factors.

Prerequisites:Merchandising major; a C or better in FAME 30293. Two hours lecture and one lab per week. Testing and analyzing the performance of textile products using standardized test methods and industry specifications. Emphasis is on identifying quality and performance characteristics of sewn products.
Prerequisites: Merchandising major, a grade of C or better in FAME 30253.  Emphasis on analysis of buying, merchandise planning, sales forecasting, inventory planning, and assortment planning.

Prerequisites: TCU cumulative 2.5 GPA, Merchandising major, a grade of C or better in FAME 30253, 30263, or 30293 and 30292.  Supervised full-time work experience in a fashion related establishment. Weekly journals, assigned papers and projects will be required.
Prerequisites:  Permission of Instructor.  Hours to be arranged. Special problems requiring independent research and study within a related area, or field experience in design.  (1-6 semester hours)
High School Investor Challenge.  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)
Freshman Seminar in Finance.

Prerequisites:   Admission to the TIP Board Program required.  Permission number needed.   This course is designed to increase student knowledge of transactional investments within corporations who specialize in investment banking, investment management, and private equity. In doing so, the course provides students direction and guidance as they make career decisions. A large portion of the course focuses on getting students prepared for recruiting in these specified areas of finance. During the course, students will be paired with two alumni mentors as part of the TIP Board Program.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite: ACCT 20353 with a grade of at least C- and INSC 20153 with a grade of at least C- for Business Majors.  ACCT 20353 with a grade of at least C- and either MATH 10043 or 30853 with a grade of at least a C- for Economics or Actuarial Science Majors.  Decision making in the financial environment. Emphasis on the acquisition and optimum management of funds. The relationship between financial management and economics, accounting, law and various functional areas of business is stressed. Working capital management, capital budgeting, short- and long-term financing, investment analysis and related topics.  Credit will not be given for both FINA 30153 and 30653.

3 hours. Prerequisite: ECON 10223, 10233, FINA 30153 with a grade of at least C-, and must be a declared Business major. Nature, function, and operations of our money and banking system. Modern monetary and banking theory, monetary policy, and their relationship to domestic and international economic and financial problems and issues.

3 hours. Prerequisite: FINA 30153 with a grade of at least C-, and must be a declared Business major or Finance minor. Investment management from the perspective of the individual investor. Financial analysis of stocks, bonds, and other financial instruments. An examination of the securities markets and the trade-off between risk and return. Attention to contemporary investment problems.

Prerequisites:  Must be a declared Business major or Finance minor with C- or above in FINA 30213.  The objective of this course is to increase students' ability to formulate and solve real-world financial problems using standard tools from the financial industry, particularly Excel and VBA.

3 hours. Prerequisites: FINA 30153, 30203, and 30213 with a grade of at least C- in each course, and must be a declared  Business major. A survey of the development and economic functions of options and futures and their markets. Includes development of pricing models, trading strategies, and portfolio management considerations.

3 hours. Prerequisite: Must be a declared Business major. Fundamentals of major types of insurance, including life, fire, accident and health, automobile, worker's compensation, transportation, and fidelity and surety bonds. Designed to acquaint the student with the general principles of insurance and their application to personal and business situations.

3 hours. Prerequisite: Must be a declared Business major. Introduction to real estate principles and practices, activities of real estate brokers and operators, transfer of real property and real estate securities, essentials of real estate law, practices incidental to ownership and control of real property.

3 hours. Prerequisite: FINA 30313 with a grade of at least C-, and must be a declared Business major. Theory, methods and principles of valuation; cost, market and income approaches to value; the appraisal process applied both to residential and commercial property.

Prerequisites:  Completion of ACCT 20653 with a grade of at least a C or ACCT 20353 with a grade of at least a C-.  Students may not receive credit for both FINA 30153 and FINA 30653.  Decision making in the financial environment.  Making the best use of resources including the acquisition and management of funds.  Financial analysis of stocks, bonds, and other financial instruments.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite: Departmental permission, and must be a declared Business major.  Preparation for and completion of a departmental honors project in the student's area of concentration in business under the direction of an assigned faculty member.  May be taken for up to three credit hours.

3 hours. Prerequisite: FINA 30153 and FINA 30203 and credit for, or concurrent enrollment in FINA 30233, and must be a declared Business major or Finance Minor. An advanced course in the application of the theory of corporate finance to real problems in business. Taught primarily by the case method, topics include financial analysis and planning, forecasting the financial needs of a firm, capital expenditure analysis, capital structure and distribution policies, merger and acquisition analysis, and corporate restructuring. Emphasis is placed on the effects of the firm's financial and operating decisions on the value of the firm's securities in financial markets.

3 hours. Prerequisite: FINA 30153 and FINA 30213, and must be a declared Business major or Finance minor. Admission by approval of the dean of the Neeley School. Participation in the operation of the Educational Investment Fund student-managed investment portfolio.

3 hours. Prerequisite: FINA 30153 and FINA 30213, and must be a declared Business major or Finance minor. Admission by approval of the dean of the Neeley School. Participation in the operation of the Educational Investment Fund student-managed investment portfolio.

3 hours. Prerequisite: FINA 30153 and 30203 with a grade of at least C- in each course, and must be a declared Business major, or consent of instructor.  Problems of commercial banks and financial institutions, primarily from the perspective of the management of an individual institution, with emphasis on formulating appropriate policies concerning the asset, liability, and capital management of the firm.

Prerequisites: FINA 30213, and must be a declared Business major or Finance minor.  This course is a comprehensive course integrating fundamental topics related to financial analysis.  Specific topics include ethics, economics, financial statement analysis, corporate finance, quantitative methods, portfolio management, equity analysis, fixed income analysis, and derivatives.

3 hours.  Prerequisite: FINA 30313 with a grade of at least C- in each course, and must be a declared Business major, or consent of instructor.  Acquisition and transfer of property; rights of adjoining owners; mortgages and liens; abstracts of title; recording; drafting of deeds, leases, mortgages, options.  Especially for real estate salesmen and brokers, owners, tenants.

3 hours. Prerequisite: FINA 30313 and 30153 with a grade of at least C- and must be a declared Business major or Finance minor, or consent of instructor. Investment value based on the present value of expected cash flows. Includes computer applications, the current income tax laws for real estate, mortgage law, sources of real estate credit including primary and secondary markets, government programs, and mortgage loan underwriting.

3 hours. Prerequisite: FINA 30153 and FINA 30203 with a grade of at least C- in each course, and must be a declared Business major or Finance minor, or consent of instructor. The international monetary system; speculation, hedging and arbitrage in foreign exchange and financial markets; financial management of the multinational firm; Eurocurrency and capital markets; and international banking.

3 hours.  Prerequisites: Permission of instructor, and must be a declared business major or a finance minor.  Finance minors who are not business majors must have completed or be concurrently enrolled in ECON 30223.  The objective of the class is to expose students to different aspects of financial issues from an international perspective.  The course provides the opportunity to study variations in business practices and experience distinct cultures in an international setting.  Students will have the opportunity to experience topically relevant practices, for example by visiting local firms and interacting with business people in order to obtain a firsthand understanding of the impact of global influences.
Prerequisite:  Must be a declared business major. (1 - 6 semester hours) This course may be repeated for credit.

Students in this course will travel to Budapest, Prague and Vienna and gain information from direct experiences in the artistic disciplines of dance and music, through a lens of history and culture.  This study abroad experience will introduce students to performance, creation, observation, and the development of the critical language of dance and music as they explore a range of perspectives that define the cultural and historical forces that impact the development of national identity.  With this ability to integrate, they will situate themselves inside of these societies: living art, living culture.

Prerequisite:  Enrollment is restricted to majors and minors in the College of Education, the College of Fine Arts, Harris College of Nursing and Health Sciences, Child Development, and Psychology.  Others may be admitted by the instructor on a case-by-case basis.  This multidisciplinary course will provide TCU students with the experiences and tools to design meaningful arts learning experiences for children.  Students will spend five weeks in each art content area: visual art, music, and dance.  Students will develop their creative capacities in each of these disciplines by examining and critiquing art, creating art and designing elementary art curricula.

Prerequisites:  (3) hours of ARST 10103 or DSGN 10113 or THEA 21423, or permission of instructor.  A course, which is focused on documenting experiences and environments by visual means.  Taught off campus and abroad.  Students will explore, journal, sketch, and paint en plein air while engaging with the cultural sites encountered.  Students will learn how to document their experiences and capture moments through a lens focused on the world surrounding them.  May be repeated for credit.

This course offers students direct experience of the major aspects of contemporary culture in a location abroad.  The faculty has structured a variety of field trips to facilitate the investigation of the arts in theatres, museums, galleries, concert halls, and studios and other arts allied spaces.  Students will also be able to interview a number of the people who are responsible for the abundance of the arts in the city now.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Prerequisite:  Permission of instructor.  This course will provide hands-on professional experience in interdisciplinary fine arts fields.  1-3 hours.  This course may be repeated for credit.
Special Problems in Fine Arts
General Transfer Credit

A beginning course in French intended for students with no previous knowledge of the language, or insufficient knowledge to qualify for placement into a more advanced course. The four skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing are taught at the elementary level, with an emphasis on oral proficiency in everyday situations encountered in French-speaking countries. No prerequisite.
Prerequisite: FREN 10153 with a grade of C- or better, or permission. Continuation of FREN 10153.
General Transfer Credit
General Transfer Credit

Prerequisite: FREN 10163 with a grade of C- or better or appropriate score on an approved placement test. Continues development of the skills of listening comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing on the intermediate level. Includes regular language laboratory assignments.

Prerequisite: FREN 20053 with a grade of C- or better, or permission. Enhances language skills on the intermediate level through a combination of readings and oral activities. Emphasizes acquisition of active and passive vocabulary.

Intensive study of a topic or theme in the cultural productions, politics, and structures of societies influenced by France.  This course introduces students to the methods used within cultural, social, and literary studies, including the development of critical reading and writing skills for upper level seminars.  No prerequisite.  Course is taught in English translation and encourages students to think transnationally and to understand that significant relationships exist between and among countries beyond and independent of the United States.  May be repeated for credit as topic changes.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Junior Honors Seminar.

Prerequisite: FREN 20063, with grades of C- or better, or permission. An introduction to French phonology, this course focuses on developing advanced listening, comprehension, and pronunciation skills through the study of French phonetics and the International Phonetics Alphabet.  Students will engage in performative tasks and projects based on media productions and plays to reach verbal and written competency.  Not open to heritage or native speakers of French.

Prerequisite: FREN 20063, with a grade of C- or better, or permission. This course further develops students' reading skills in French, exposing them to literary texts in a variety of genres from different periods. Includes an introduction to the study and analysis of literary works.  Not open to heritage or native French speakers.

Prerequisite: FREN 20063, with a grade of C- or better, or permission.  This course introduces students to basic elements of style and academic writing in French.  Students will learn to write short personal narratives, reviews, expository and persuasive essays, and critical analyses of literary and non-fiction texts.  In addition , students will begin to explore the characteristics of writing for the Web.2.0 environment.  Not open to native French speakers.

Prerequisite: FREN 20063 with a grade of C- or better, or permission. Study of French history, art, geography, government and customs to the revolution of 1789.  This course is not open to native speakers of French.
Prerequisite: FREN 20063 with a grade of C- or better, or permission. Continuation of 30153 from the revolution of 1789 to the present day.  This course is not open to native speakers of French.

The course explores French and migrant culture from diverse perspectives.  It incorporates readings and films about migration history, economies of labor, politics, identity, citizenship, and civic responsibilities.

Prerequisite: FREN 20063 with a grade of C- or better.  A summer course conducted by TCU in France or other francophone country.  The course offers students the opportunity to improve linguistic and cultural proficiency by interacting directly with culture and native speakers.  Students will study topics related to the region in which the program is held.

Prerequisite: FREN 20063 with a grade of C- or better, or equivalent.  This course proposes the study of several films representative of modern French cinema.  Terminology pertaining to filmmaking and an overview of cinematic techniques will be introduced at the beginning of the semester, enabling students to express their insights and impressions with accuracy, and to make meaningful cultural comparisons between French and American filmmaking styles.  Films will be supplemented by readings selected to give additional insight into their cultural and artistic significance.  These texts will consist primarily of 1) journalistic articles pertaining to historical events or social issues portrayed in the films, 2) historical documents pertaining to political situations addressed in the films, and 3) critical texts and interviews pertaining to the making of the film and their public reception.

Prerequisite: FREN 20063 with a grade of C-or better, or permission.  This course examines through the lens of the French media the main currents of ideologies in today's French society with respect to politics, education, work, family, the question of a national identity, and the relationship between France and the Francophone world, particularly in North America.  Open to Native Speakers and non-minors or majors with a demonstrated Intermediate to High proficiency in French.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite: Admission to Honors Program in Modern Languages and senior standing or permission.  Senior honors students will write a major paper on a topic agreed upon between the student and two professors, one of whom will direct the research and development of the paper.  This paper, when completed, is to be read and approved by the two designated professors of the department.
Prerequisites: FREN 30063 and 30073 with a grade of C- or better, or permission. A specific author, genre, period or theme will be chosen for study.

Prerequisites: FREN 30063 and 30073 with a grade of C- or better, or permission.  Study of French language writings from Africa, the Caribbean, Canada or other French-speaking areas.  A specific author, genre, period or theme will be chosen for study.

Prerequisites: FREN 30063 and 30073 with a grade of C- or better, or permission.  This capstone course extends the range of verbal communication and writing strategies, particularly focusing on developing persuasive communication skills.  It emphasizes reviewing the fine grammar points and diversifying vocabulary through readings in key social issues (Social Justice, Community Engagement, sustainable Living, etc.)  Furthermore, the students will complete a research project in an area of personal interest demonstrating their language proficiency and their understanding of the French and/or Francophone cultures.
Prerequisite: FREN 30073 with a grade of C- or better, or permission. Topic and credit hours announced yearly. Opportunity for independent study. 1-6 hours
General Transfer Credit-FAR credit.

Lecture and viewing sessions.  An introduction to the field of television studies, including an examination of various approaches to the study of television history and the television industry within appropriate social and cultural contexts.  Viewing of significant programming in television history.  Designed for non-majors.

Lecture and viewing sessions. Includes examination of the development of film structure and aesthetics within appropriate social and cultural contexts. Viewing of significant films in cinema history. Designed for non-majors. FTDM majors may not use this course to fulfill major requirements or Fine Arts requirement.

Examination of film/television adaptations from literature, with emphasis on the discussion of style, structure, and characterization, and on the cultural factors which affect adaptations (financial expectations of different media, censorship and self-regulation of content, etc.)  Topics may include film/television programs adapted from plays, short fiction, or novels; the course may also address novelizations of stories which first appeared as films or television programs, musical adaptations of non-musical films, and remakes.

Lecture and viewing sessions. An intensive overview of the history of radio, television and related electronic media from 1900 to the present. Topics include the rise of the network system, programming and the evolution of broadcast technology. This course is designed for majors; the minimum acceptable grade is a 2.0 "C".

Lecture and viewing sessions. An intensive history of film from 1890 to the present. Includes examination of the development of film structure within social and cultural contexts, the Hollywood studio system, and selected international cinema systems. This course is designed for majors; the minimum acceptable grade is a 2.0 "C".  FTDM 10053 may not substitute for this course.

An overview of how films and television programs can be read and analyzed in terms of artistic and narrative form. The course is designed to complement and provide a framework for all other FTDM courses. This course is designed for majors and minors; the minimum acceptable grade is a 2.0 C.

An intensive overview of significant milestones in the development of entertainment media with a primary focus on film and television. Examines significant historical contexts (industrial, cultural, technological) in which media have been produced in the United States and elsewhere. This course is designed for majors; the minimum acceptable grade is a 2.0 "C".
General Transfer Credit
Topics may vary each time it is offered.

Prerequisites:  FTDM 10143.  This course is designed to give students an overview of the production process, with the focus on pre-production planning.  Students will learn how to acquire and develop a property, the basics of production financing, budgeting, scheduling, production and set management.  Students will learn the role and responsibilities of jobs relating to film and television production, and the basic skills needed to perform those functions.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 10123 or FTDM 21713; FTDM and Sports Broadcasting majors only.  Students will learn the basics of video production, including principles of camera work, shot composition, audio techniques, and basic lighting concepts, through a series of lectures and labs.  This class provides students with a foundation for advanced production classes.

Prerequisites:  A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 20113; FTDM majors only.  This course will build upon the skills learned in the pre-production course, introducing students to the practical skillset required to produce professional content relevant in today's industry.  Students will explore multiple examples of production including narrative film and television, non-fiction film and digital marketing content.  Students will also be introduced to the principles of post-production, in preparation for the next course in the production sequence.  Students will shoot and edit individual and collaborative projects, working to create professional material to include in their portfolio.

Prerequisites:  FTDM majors only: a 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 10153 or permission of the department.  Maximum 3 semester hours; 1-3 semester hours per semester.  Students will study basic radio station operations, including announcing, writing for radio, basic audio production, programming fundamentals, and promotions.  The class includes 9 hours of on-air lab work, per weeks, at KTCU FM 88.7 (this could include some nights and weekends).  Hours of lab TBD.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 10153; FTDM majors and Sports Broadcasting majors only. This course provides an intensive overview of radio, TV, and film business practices, including the structure of media companies; how media conceptualize and measure their audience; strategies (i.e., promotion, advertising) media companies use to attract an audience, and regulatory structures that govern the radio, TV, and film industries.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisites: FTDM and Sports Broadcasting Majors only.  Overview and analysis of sports broadcasting.  This course teaches the fundamentals of both on-air talent and behind-the-scenes production of both television and radio sports production.  This course is a foundation course for students majoring in sports broadcasting.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 21713 and Sports Broadcasting majors only.  Students will learn the basics of sports video production, including principles of single-camera production and basic sports post-production techniques through a series of lectures and labs. This class provides students with a foundation for advanced production classes.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 21113; Sports Broadcasting majors only.  This class is designed to give students practical experience working in a radio station sports department.  Students will produce a variety of TCU sports, cut promos, live-sports updates and pre- and postgame shows on KTCU-FM.

Prerequisites: FTDM or Sports Broadcasting majors only.  This course teaches students the basic skills and techniques necessary to work in the sports production business.  Students will serve as crew on TCU sports broadcasts.  This course provides hands-on learning opportunities for students and serves as a primer for progression in the major.

Prerequisites: Junior standing and membership in the Honors Program. This course is offered only as a tutorial and the specific topic is determined by consultation with an instructor. Arrangements for this course must be made with an instructor the semester prior to enrollment.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 10143; Open to majors in FTDM and Cinema and Media Studies and to Film and Media Studies minors. ENGL 10803.  Students in this course will develop a critical perspective on broadcasting and film.  Intensive practice in analyzing and writing about broadcast programs and motion pictures.

Prerequisite: A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 10153; By reading and viewing plays and screenplays of various eras and genres, students will learn to identify the structural components of narrative drama and to analyze their usage in a variety of works, providing them with tools to more effectively write and direct original screenplays.

Prerequisite: A 2.0 C grade in FTDM 10153 and 20213, or in 20313.  Advanced audio production and editing.  Sound design for film and television.  Multitrack music recording and mastering.  Field recording and sound-effect production.  Foley sound, editing for voice acting and dialog replacement.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20213 or in 20313.  This course focuses on advanced production work for narrative dramatic projects.  Students will create and execute single-camera productions designed to give them hands-on experience and build on the skill set learned in other production classes.  The course culminates with students producing productions that may be entered into video festivals.  These projects will allow students to use equipment such as SteadyCams, Micro Dollies, Jibs, Green Screen, etc.

Prerequisite: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20213 or 20313.  An extensive exploration of the tools and techniques used by the cinematographer.  Lectures will cover the evolving technologies of film and HD filmmaking with an emphasis on filmspace, visual language, lens language, camera dynamics, cinematic continuity, exposure, the tools of lighting, color theory and lighting as storytelling.  Weekly labs will include lighting workshops in the studio with emphasis on single camera film production.  Students will work on individual projects culminating with a film production.

Prerequisite: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 10153 and 20213, or in 20313.  This course focuses on the role of the director in film and television.  Students learn to breakdown scripts, block actors and camera, develop characters, work with actors to get a performance, and oversee the various department heads involved with film and television production.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 10153 and 20213, or in 20313.  Working with AVID and Final Cut Studio non-linear editing software, students will edit commercials, narrative films, and take projects through the on-line process of color correction, special effects, and exporting the project to its final distribution form.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 "C" or higher in FTDM 10153.  An exploration of the theories and techniques of on-camera performance. Students act in student-directed video projects and critique their work in class. Projects and assignments focus on improving performance skills as well as developing strategies to work with talent in a production setting.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 30313 or 40333.  This course provides students with the aesthetic skills and technical knowledge needed to develop and implement Web design and interactive media as well as titles and graphics, process shots, and special effects for film and video.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher grade in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103.  This course examines one or more film and/or TV genres, considering how we define genres, how genres have developed in relation to changes in the film and TV industries, and how audiences have responded to different genres.  Selection of genres varies by semester, can be repeated with another topic.  (6 semester hours maximum; 3 hours per semester)

Lecture and viewing sessions. An overview of the history of American cinema from 1895 to the present. Includes examination of the development of American film from a cultural and historical perspective. Topics include Hollywood system, Independent cinema, Ethnic cinema, and Minority cinema. Open to non-majors. Course is not repeatable for credit.

This course explores how crime and punishment have been depicted throughout film history, focusing on the relation between culture and the movies.  Topics include audiences' continuing interest in crime films, the censorship battles which have been triggered by movies about crime, and the treatment of specific historical figures such as Al Capone and John Dillinger.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103 .  This course examines media texts in their historical and cultural contexts, considering how film, TV shows, and other media both reflect and affect the time and place in which they are made.  Each decade can only be taken once.  (6 semester hours maximum; 3 hours per semester.)  May be repeated for credit under different decades.

Films about historical events may inspire us to learn more about history; however, they may also present us with inaccurate information, and they are always subjective.  This course examines how specific historical events and the lives of historical figures have been depicted in Hollywood films.  The course will examine the typical structures and themes of these "based-on-a-true-story" movies and how changing cultural attitudes affect the depiction of specific events from the past.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103.  In this course, students will study the concept of authorship in media production, which is always in essence a collaborative endeavor.  In this course, students will identify individual creative vision by viewing film and/or TV texts and how authorship has been seen historically in the media industries and by audiences.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 20510 and permission of instructor.  FTDM majors only.  (maximum 6 semester hours; 3 hours maximum per semester.)  Practicum in operations of a radio stations.  Students will do more advanced audio production, organize and conduct promotions, and may also serve in management roles in programming, music, news, and/or sports.  The class included 9 hours of lab work per week, at KTCU FM 88.7 (this could include some nights and weekends).  Hours of lab TBD.

Prerequisites: C grade or higher in JOUR 30204 or permission of instructor. Principles and techniques or developing successful social media campaigns and website analytics for news media.  Course focuses on ethical issues posed by social media marketing in journalism, as well as research, promotion strategies, brand identity creative execution.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 20523; FTDM and Sports Broadcasting majors only. Historical overview of TV programming trends. Current program practices and strategies in cable, satellite, internet, and mobile television media.

Prerequisite: A 2.0 C or higher grade in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103.  Explores issues in the relationships among television, culture, and society. Emphasis on understanding the role television has played in the development of mass culture and the influence of television on contemporary society.

Prerequisites:  A 2.0 grade or higher in FTDM 20523; FTDM and Sports Broadcasting majors only.  In this course, we will take an in-depth examination of film and television franchises--how they are created and established, maintained, and propagated.  Through our readings and discussions, we will explore the definitions of the terms "branding: and "franchise" and what they mean within the contemporary media landscape.

Prerequisite: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 10143, or permission of instructor.  Using a cultural/historical perspective, this course focuses upon postcolonial, social, economic, and political factors that create the visual image in British cinema.  Investigates the representation of Britain's identity in European culture.  Examined through a series of seminars, guest lectures, and on-site visits to studios and museums in London.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 10153, and 20523, or permission of instructor.  Examines the increasingly global nature of the film and broadcasting industries, and explores the impact of US films abroad, using the British market as a specific subject of analysis.  Includes a series of seminars, guest lectures, and on-site visits to studios and museums in London.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher grade in FTDM 20523.  A comprehensive examination of television series that were ranked number one in the Nielsen ratings for one or more TV seasons between 1950 and the present, with a focus on the significance of these series and their impact on the television industry.

Prerequisites:  A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 20523; FTDM and Sports Broadcasting majors only.  This class will examine issues related to the digital delivery
of content.  Through readings and discussions, this class will explore digital distribution practices and how they function in the contemporary media landscape.

Prerequisites: FTDM and Sports Broadcasting majors only.  Permission of department is required.  Students must have completed 21 hours of FTDM courses including FTDM 20523 or FTDM 21113 with a 2.0 C or higher grade, and at least one of the following courses (with a 2.0 C or higher): FTDM 20213, 20313, 21213, 21713, 30313 or 40333. Supervised study, experience, and on-the-job training in a media-related organization. May only be taken on a pass-no credit basis. This course is required for Sports Broadcasting majors.  FTDM majors or minors may use this class as an elective only (1-6 semester hours, 3 hours maximum per semester.)  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)

This course examines the relationship between women and the electronic media. Specific issues include the social construction of gender and gender roles, the influence of media stereotypes, and the critical evaluation of artistic works created by female writers, producers, and directors.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 10113, 21113, and 21713; Sports Broadcasting majors only.  This course gives the student practical hands-on experience in live sporting events such as: football, baseball, basketball, soccer, tennis and other sports.  Students will be responsible for all aspects of the production from director to camera operator.  This course is a foundation course for sports broadcasting majors.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 21713 and 31713 or permission of instructor. Sports Broadcasting majors only. This course will prepare students as producers, directors, associate producers, assistant directors and time out coordinators for live television sports productions. Combining lecture and lab, students will learn all of the necessary skills needed to produce and direct live television sports productions. Students enrolled in this course will have the opportunity to produce and direct TCU sporting events that will air on ESPN Plus.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 10153 and 21113; Sports
Broadcasting majors only. Theory and application of audio for sports
broadcasting. This class looks at the techniques for live sports television
and radio. Includes microphone choice and placement, mixing
techniques, IFB, and replay video monitor deployment. Labs include
actual onsite broadcasts of sporting events (live to tape). This is not a
play-by-play announcing course.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisites: FTDM 30003. Senior standing and membership in the Honors Program. A supervised research experience and a thesis that is usually based on the subject matter studied in 30003. This course is offered only as a tutorial; arrangements must be made with an instructor prior to enrollment.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 10153 and 30153.  Building on the knowledge acquired in Dramatic Style and Structure, students will develop, create, write and revise original screenplays.  Conducted as a workshop, all scripts are read aloud and critiqued by the class with the ultimate goal of developing a script suitable for production.

Prerequisite: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20213 or 20313; FTDM majors only.  This course will focus on a particular production-related area not covered elsewhere in the curriculum.  It provides a chance for students to pursue in-depth study in such areas as music, sound design, cinematography, post-production, production management, writing, directing, and others.  Up to 6 semester hours, maximum of 3 hours per semester.

Prerequisite: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20523.  An examination of legal and financial issues related to film and television production. Topics covered may include employment contracts, permits and releases, music licensing, guilds and unions, financing, and production and distribution revenues and expenses.  Counts as industry credit.
Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20213 or 20313.  Through an examination of documentary styles and journalistic techniques, students will produce, write, direct, and edit a documentary.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103.  Using a variety of theoretical and critical approaches, students will examine limited topics such as films produced within a particular time period, films by specific directors, or film which are unified by theme or style.  (6 hours maximum; 3 hours per semester).
Prerequisite: A 2.0 "C" or higher in FTDM 20523.  Structural and content regulation of the media industries.  Court cases bearing on media industries.  Introduction to legal research and writing.

Prerequisite: A 2.0 "C" or higher in FTDM 20523; FTDM majors only.  An in-depth examination of selected issues relating to media industry business practices.  (6 semester hours maximum; 3 hours per semester)

Prerequisite: A 2.0 C or higher grade in FTDM 20523; FTDM and Sports Broadcasting majors only. The organization and administration of broadcast, cable and film operations. Management techniques and strategies, including forecasting, planning, statistical and financial analysis, and interpersonal communication.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 "C" or higher in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103.  An in-depth analysis or selected television genres and industry practices from a variety of critical and theoretical perspectives.  (6 semester hours maximum; 3 hours per semester)

Prerequisite: A C or higher in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103. In this course, students will study the production, circulation, and styles of international films.  (6 semester hours maximum; 3 hours per semester)
Prerequisites: A 2.0 "C" or higher in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103.  This course will examine noteworthy topics pertaining to popular culture as represented/communicated in two or more types of media.

This course explores how popular music functions as a significant media industry and source of culture in contemporary society and explores the technology that made music recording and distribution possible.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103.  Students in this course will examine current trends in various media forms, looking at the ways texts, the industry, and audiences intersect in contemporary practice.  May be repeated for credit under different topics.  (6 semester hours maximum; 3 hours per semester.)
Prerequisite: A 2.0 "C" or higher grade in FTDM 20583 or FTDM 30103.  Survey of classical and contemporary film theories.
An overview of contemporary media in Great Britain, focusing on the press, television, and cinema.  Taught only in London.

Prerequisite: Junior standing; a 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 10143 and 10153.  A conference course designed to give an individual student opportunities for additional specialized work in his or her area of concentration.  Prerequisites may vary for different sections of this course.  1-6 semester hours

Prerequisite: By permission only. FTDM, Sports Broadcasting and Cinema and Media Studies majors only. Students must be in last semester of senior year. A review and synthesis of material covered in the FTDM, Sports Broadcasting and Cinema and Media Studies majors. This course is required for FTDM, Sports Broadcasting and Cinema and Media Study majors; the minimum acceptable grade is a 2.0 "C." (1 semester hour)

Prerequisites:  A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 21113.  This course is designed to give students an opportunity to put into practice play-by-play, color analyst, and sideline reporting skills that were taught in prior classes.  The class gives students a chance to put pre-production, background research and interview skills into practice by calling games for television and radio broadcasts.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 21213.  This course examines the principles and techniques of non-linear editing for use in sports.  Students will spend time on the department's non-linear editing systems.  The course will explore the theory and practice of sports editing, and use examples ranging from long form documentaries to sports highlight shows.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20213 or 21213; Sports broadcasting majors only.  Students in the course will explore the theory and practice documentary production for the sports broadcasting industry.  Students will examine different forms of documentary storytelling, ranging from Ken Burn's Baseball to NFL films.  Students will also research and create documentaries that may be aired.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 "C" or higher in FTDM 21113 or permission of instructor.  An in-depth examination of selected issues relating to the sports media industry.  (6 semester hours maximum; 3 hours per semester)

Prerequisites:  A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 21213 and 21713; Sports Broadcasting majors only.  This course will focus on a particular sports production-related area not covered elsewhere in the curriculum.  It provides an opportunity for students to pursue in-depth study in specific topics, practices, and issues related to sports production.  6 semester hours maximum, as topics vary; limit to 3 hours per semester.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 21113 and 20523; Sports Broadcasting majors only.  This course will examine legal issues, rights fees, and problems associated with producing an event overseas.  Students will examine what is needed to produce sports events internationally, such as the Olympics, World Cup Soccer, Skiing, Sailing, and Golf, and how television networks overcome the problems associated with international broadcasting.

Prerequisites: A 2.0 C or higher in FTDM 20523; FTDM majors only.  An advanced exploration of film and video producing, with an examination of techniques used by producers and financial, budgeting, and legal issues facing today's producers.  All phases of the producing process will be examined, from acquiring the property, to pre-production, principal photography and post-production, as well as distribution.

Prerequisites: Preference is given to juniors and seniors.  Permission of instructor and/or department chair.  This course develops the student's ability to analyze, establish and execute external and internal communication goals, strategies and tactics for a client.  Students use research, discussion, peer evaluation and instructor assessment to produce creative and effective solutions to marketing and promotion challenges.  The course places students in the role of communication professionals working with the Bob Schieffer College of Communication and other TCU academic units and organizations as their clients.

Prerequisites:  A 2.0 C grade or higher in FTDM 20583 or 30103; Cinema and Media Studies majors only.  A capstone course in which Cinema and Media studies majors produce a comprehensive research project that utilizes relevant film, media, and/or cultural theories to guide the process of in-depth media analysis.
Prerequisites: Senior or graduate standing. Seminar in radio, television, and film. 3-6 semester hours; maximum 3 semester hours per semester.

Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing.  A conference course designed to give an individual student opportunities for additional specialized work in his or her area of concentration. (1-6 semester hours)
General Transfer Credit-SSC credit.

A survey of the world's primary regions and the human and physical geography that shape them.  Interactions between natural environment, cultural geography, geopolitics, history, land use, and economic geography are highlighted.

This course examines the processes that shape our environment and the resulting patterns of landforms, biomes, climates, and water resources.  Students will analyze interactions among dynamic systems in the lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere using basic scientific principles and methods, with an emphasis on spatial relationships.  Students will also consider the relationship between humans and the environment, including the distribution of resources and adaptation to and modification of environments.  The course will be lecture with integrated lab.

This course introduces students to the field of urban studies in global context.  Major urban themes covered in the class include urban form; neighborhood change; real estate; environmental management; race and immigration; suburbanization; migration and slums; and cities within the global economy.  These themes are explored through case studies of major cities around the world.
General Transfer Credit
Transfer work with TCUCC-SSC credit.
GEOG Transfer Credit - SSC only
Transfer work with TCUCC-SSC credit.
Geography transfer credit with SSC credit only.

The systematic subdivisions of human geography are surveyed, including urban, cultural, political, economic, historical, agricultural, and population geography.  Within each subdiscipline, applications of geographic concepts and processes are emphasized.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  For geography majors who are Honors students as well as other students with overall GPAs at or above 3.5, who are willing to join the Honors College.  Permission by a geography faculty member required.  Directed study course for students who intend to complete a Seniors Honors Thesis research paper or equivalent creative project in a selected area of geography.

This course is an introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS), with a focus on both the conceptual foundations and applications of GIS software.  Topics covered include spatial data models; cartographic design; coordinate systems and map projections; address geocoding and GPS data; spatial analysis; Internet GIS applications; and GIS modeling.  Laboratory assignments give students experience using GIS in thematic areas such as demographic analysis, market research, and urban environmental change.

Data literacy is essential to success in many professional fields.  In this course, students will gain experience acquiring, manipulating, and analyzing data; and will learn how to effectively communicate their findings with static and interactive visualizations.  Students will learn how to work with data using the Python programming language, one of the most popular tools for performing data analysis.

This course is an introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS), with a focus on the use of GIS for applications that are important for real estate professionals. No prior knowledge of GIS is assumed for this course, although students should have some facility with basic mathematics, statistics, and spreadsheet programs. Students will develop familiarity with leading GIS software programs and build experience managing property-related databases, conductinglocational analysis, site-suitability analyses, mapping market trends, risk-assessment, and utilizing GIS to navigate permitting, zoning, and other regulatory processes.

An analysis of the human and physical geography of a specific region.  Examples of regions include Texas, Sub-Saharan Africa, and Eastern Europe.  Regional characteristics investigated may include economic, political, historical, and cultural components as well as topography, climate, and natural resources.  May be repeated for credit provided the specified region changes.

An exploration of the human and physical geography of the United States.  Areas of the country, such as the Pacific Northwest and New England, will be surveyed, analyzing the physical, historic, cultural, and economic characteristics that embody their unique regional identities.

An exploration of the human and physical geography of Latin America.  This course analyzes Latin America from a geographical perspective and addresses topics such as landforms, climate, environmental hazards, indigenous peoples, culture, ethnicity, religion, agriculture, political geography, population, cities, and economic production.

An exploration of the human and physical geography of Western Europe.  Countries and regions of the realm will be surveyed, analyzing their economic, political, language and religious characteristics as well as topography, climate, and natural resources.  Themes may include the impact of population trends, environmental problems, trade and economic development, interactions between ethnic groups, and geopolitical change.

Concepts, principles, patterns, and processes associated with a specific subdiscipline in geography.  Examples of topics include Economic Geography, Geopolitics, Medical Geography, and Physical Geography.  May be repeated for credit provided the specified subdiscipline changes.

Urban Geography is the geographical study of cities.  Examples of topics include: urban ecosystems; the role of physical geography in the origins and growth of cities; theoretical models of urban size, location, and land use structure; the internal geography of urban economic and social activity; and international and historical variation in the form, functions, and degree of urbanization.

Cultural Geography is the study of human culture from the perspectives of its five geographic themes: culture region, diffusion and migration, cultural ecology, cultural landscape, and cultural integration.  Each theme is applied to a variety of topics, which may include religion, language, cultural conflict, folk culture, popular culture, and demography.

The Geography of Religion is the study of religion from the spatial perspective, utilizing the five themes of cultural geography: region, diffusion, culture-environment interaction, landscapes, and integration.  Our most important topics cover the relationship between physical geography and religion, and from this context we will analyze religions, past and present.
Problem-solving by application of geographic concepts, methodologies, and techniques.  Examples are drawn from physical and human geography.

In this course, students engage with contemporary debates around world population growth and change.  Course topics include demographic data and methods; the history and future of world population growth; fertility and population control in the developing world; aging in the developed world; global trends in mortality and disease; internal migration and immigration; and population, climate change, and environmental sustainability.

Economic Geography is the study of how elements within the economy are spatially arranged, as well as the ways that space, place and spatial scales shape economic activities in different parts of the world.  Through a series of readings, discussions, and research assignments, this course examines the distribution of economic activities on the earth's surface; market resource and transportation factors in location theory, and the role of state, market and civil society's agents in management of the economy.  Students are further introduced to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) through content-focused lab assignments, though no previous experience with GIS is required for this course.

This course uses beer (and wine) as a lens to examine the intersections of historical, environmental, cultural, legal, and economic geography.  Students are introduced to the major systematic fields of Geographic inquiry:  Historical Geography, Cultural Geography, Economic Geography, etc through focused lessons examining the role of beer production in the establishment of historical civilizations, how climate change affects barley and hop production, and the locational characteristics required for a brewery or brewpub to be successful.

Since mass tourism's emergence in the late 19th century, tourism has played an increasingly significant role in shaping and reshaping the geographies of places around the world.  This course pays specific attention to the ways in which places develop into tourist destinations, as well as the social, environmental, economic, and political ramifications of that development.

This course covers the study of sport through the lens of social science.  It introduces students to social scientific theory and analytic methods in the context of historical and contemporary sports topics.  Course topics include sports and cultural geography; sports and nationalism; race, gender, politics, and sports; sports business and economics; and sports analytics.

This course number will be used for trial runs of upper-division environmentally-focused Geography courses.  All the classes will develop student's understanding of Environmental Geography and Human-Environment Interactions.  May be repeated for credit as course topic changes.

This course examines relationships between people and the environment from multiple perspectives, providing a context for thinking about the causes and consequences of environmental change and their spatial patterns around the world.  Of particular interest are the cultural, ethical, economic, technological, and population considerations that make humans want to use, protect, destroy, or adapt to environmental systems and their components.  This course will also address the function of specific environmental systems themselves, including how they influence and respond to human actions.

In this course, we will examine the spatial dimensions of highly contentious issues surrounding nuclear technologies, including power generation, weapons, and medicine.  We will approach each of these issues through the perspectives offered by several subdisciplines within Geography, especially Environmental, Economic, Political, and Cultural Geography.

This course introduces students to urban economic development (UED) policy and strategy in the United States. In particular, students are encouraged to respectfully and thoughtfully address the assumptions and biases embedded in urban economic development policy. For example, final papers will examine the presence or lack thereof of equity and sustainability aims in economic development initiatives, and analyze UED projects that respond to the specific challenges of rising inequality and climate change that threaten UED activity in the US and worldwide.
Topical studies in Geography.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Prerequisites: GEOG 30003 or permission of instructor.  A senior Honors Thesis research paper or equivalent creative project, under faculty direction, in a selected area of geography.

An intensive field study in the regional and systematic geography of a selected area.  Examples include France, Central America, and the American West.  May be repeated for credit provided the selected area changes.

Prerequisites:  GEOG 30313 or equivalent training with instructor's approval.
This course is only open to Geography majors.  The purpose of this course is to supplement the internship experience of geography majors through 
written reflection, periodic conversation with a supervising professor, and exploration of connections between concepts in GIS and practices of GIS in different disciplines. Students may take this course a maximum of two times to earn up to 6 total credit hours. A maximum of 3 credit hours can be applied towards the Geography major. The remaining credit hours can be applied to the 
student's overall degree as general elective credits.

Prerequisites:  GEOG 30313 or with instructor permission.  This course number will be used for trial runs of upper-division technically-focused Geography courses.  All the classes will develop student's technical mapping and analysis skills using Geographic Information Systems software and/or statistical programs such as R or Python.  May be repeated for credit provided the technical and/or topical focus changes.

Prerequisites: GEOG 30313, or instructor consent.  In this course, students gain experience with advanced applications of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) software.  Topics covered include GIS modeling; web GIS applications and distributed GIS services; open-source GIS; developing geoprocessing scripts using the Python programming language; and the current state of the GIS profession.  Students will also complete a semester-long course project in which they apply GIS techniques to a topic of their interest.

Prerequisites: GEOG 30313; another introductory GIS course; or instructor consent.  This advanced GIS course gives students experience applying GIS to solve real-world urban and business problems.  Topics covered include demographic analysis; remote sensing of urban areas; network analysis; 3D urban modeling; spatial statistics; time and GIS; geodemographic classification; market area analysis; and web GIS services.  Students will also complete a semester-long group project that applies GIS to assist an organization or business in the Fort Worth area.

Prerequisites:  GEOG 30313 or with instructor permission.  Cartography refers to the art and science of map-making. Contemporary cartography is primarily accomplished using digital technologies including Geographic Information
Systems (GIS). Mapping is crucial to exploring and understanding distributions of
geographic phenomena. It is also an important phase of many database-intensive analyses, because a map is often the best way to visualize results and show them to others. Our emphases in this course will be on designing and producing both thematic and reference maps at multiple scales using symbols and visual hierarchies that allow the content of the maps to be effectively communicated and presented in aesthetically-pleasing and/or engaging ways. Topics covered include: significant eras in cartographic design, key historical and contemporary cartographers, map projections, symbolizing quantitative data, use of space, layout, compilation, verbal content, and the use of computer technology
in the design and production of maps.

This course provides an in-depth exploration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) with a focus on large language models (LLMs) and their applications in Geography.  Students will gain foundational knowledge in AI and deep learning, develop skills in prompt engineering, and apply AI tools to solve real-world problems, particularly in geographic analysis and spatial data interpretation.  The course emphasizes hands-on experience, ethical considerations, and culminates in a final project where students integrate AI concepts to design their own applications with a geographic focus.

Supervised reading, research, and preparation of a substantial paper focused on a specific regional analysis or topical subdiscipline of geography.  Regional characteristics investigated may include economic, political, historical, and cultural components as well as topography, climate, and natural resources.  Examples of topics include advanced studies in Urban Geography, Cultural Geography, Geopolitics, and Historical Geography.
General Transfer Credit-NSC credit.
General Transfer Credit

Two hours lecture and two hours of laboratory per week. A study of the physical environment of the planet Earth, its makeup, the processes that mold its surface features and an introduction to the resources that it provides.
General Transfer Credit
Freshman Seminar in Geology.
General Transfer Credit
Transfer work with NSC and GA credit.

Prerequisites:  GEOL 10113 should be completed or in progress. All students who are new geology majors must take this course.  All new geology majors will be introduced to the Geology Faculty, their areas of research and teaching,
and the expectations of the Faculty. Majors will also be introduced to the department, its facilities, expectations for field trips and work, and information on careers and areas of the geosciences.

Introductory level course, with integrated lecture and laboratory experience, focusing on Earth as a system of interacting spheres. The course will cover interactions between Earth's biosphere (including people), geosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere and consequences for current and future population, life expectancy, food, climate, water availability and water quality. Emphasis is placed on how basic scientific knowledge and readily available data can be used in understanding Earth Systems.

Prerequisite: GEOL 10113.  Three hours lecture per week.  For the non-science major.  Places society's relationship to geological phenomena within a scientific framework.  Evaluates the apparent immutability of the earth.  Field trip required.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Reading assignments and discussions on topics of great importance in geology.

This three-credit hour lecture course will examine the connections between science and modern society.  This will be accomplished by investing the role of science (particularly geoscience) in education and communication, and how scientific misconceptions influence public perception and understanding of modern socioscientific issues such as dwindling freshwater resources and climate change.

Prerequisites:  'C-' or better in GEOL 10113 and GEOL 20113.  This 2.0 credit hour course is designed to introduce students to the field of geoscience education. This course will cover the nature of geoscience education, and the need for geoscience education specialists.   Specifically, students will define geoscience education within the context of other science disciplines, examine how geoscientists think about learning, how students learn in geoscience classrooms, and investigate the role of geoscience education toward addressing modern socioscientific issues.

Three hours lecture per week. Introduction to the basic concepts and principles of atmospheric science in a descriptive format; emphasizes the physics responsible for changes in weather and climate complemented with popular treatment.  (Crosslisted as ENSC/GEOL 30113)

Three hours lecture per week.  Prerequisite: GEOL 10113 or consent of instructor.  A broad-based inquiry into dinosaurs, the biological and geological aspects of their world and those who study them.  We will approach dinosaurs from many different fields of science in an attempt to reconstruct their world.  The course is intended for science and non-science students.

Prerequisite: GEOL 10113 or equivalent.  This first semester of a two semester lab/lecture introduces students to the general principles of earth history.  Lab exercises and field trips introduce students to the practical aspects of earth history.  Microscope work and field trips are mandatory.

Prerequisite GEOL 30133 or equivalent. This second semester of a two semester lab/lecture course continues with an in depth look at the details of the geological history of North America and the history of life on earth. Lectures focus on historical detail, while lab exercises and field trips focus on major groups of fossils in the lab and field. Microscope work and field trips are mandatory.

Prerequisites: GEOL 10113, or permission of instructor.  Study of dynamic geologic systems and the geology of the North American continent through the study of National Parks and Monuments in the United States.  The three hours of lecture per week are designed for science majors and interested non-science majors, who wish to gain in-depth knowledge of processes that actively sculpt and have sculpted our continent through time.  Particular emphasis is given to interpretation of visual features of the parks through visual aids.  Discussions are encouraged and facilitated by the small class size.

Prerequisites: GEOL 10113, or any one of PHYS 10164/10263/10273, or permission of instructor.  Three hours of lectures per week.
