The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Upper Level LANG generic course

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisites:  SPAN 32703 or 32803 or equivalent.
This is a critical study of contemporary Latin America from an interdisciplinary perspective within the social sciences, the humanities, and the arts, among others.  This capstone course brings together the study of language, culture, and literature.  Course must be taken in residence at TCU during the senior year.

This course is an introduction to the study of characteristics and experiences of the Latina/o community in the United States.  As we review the historical, social, political, religious, anthropological aspects, among others, we will evaluation the diversity within the community in order to locate this group within the United States society.  Finally, we will concentrate on topics that are relevant to this group, like immigration, transnationalism, popular culture, among others.
General Transfer Credit
Topics may vary each time it is offered.

3 hours.  Prerequisites: Business minor and ACCT 20653 with minimum grade of C.   This course will examine legal issues that arise in the course of doing business.  Following an introduction to court systems and dispute resolution, the course will examine various business torts, contract law, the law of principal and agent, intellectual property, employment law and securities regulation.
Prerequisite:  Must be a business major. (1-6 semester hours) This course may be repeated for credit.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript will be included in the student's grade point average.

3 hours. Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, and must be a declared pre-business or declared business major.  Tasks of the manager are studied in the context of his/her role as an administrative decision maker. Emphasis placed on understanding the organization as a system where the manager needs to examine a variety of variables in order to arrive at problem solutions. Management processes, system concepts, models for decision making, and behavioral concepts involving motivation, leadership, group activity, conflict and change are covered.  Students may not receive credit for both MANA 30153 and MANA 30653.

1.5 hours. Prerequisite: Sophomore standing and must be a business major. Corequisite: Concurrent enrollment in MANA 40250 is required. This course covers essential skills in Organizational Behavior, including individual differences and
perspective taking, motivation and performance management, leadership and power, communication, interpersonal relationships and networks, and conflict and negotiation. Students are strongly encouraged to take this course early in their program to get an overview of topics associated with the Management major and Leadership Minor.

Prerequisites:  MANA 30153 with a grade of at least C or concurrent enrollment, and must be a declared business major.  This course and BUSI 30833 cannot both be taken for credit.  This course is designed to provide an in-depth analysis of leadership development from theoretical and practical perspectives.  An emphasis is placed on opportunities for introspection regarding the manifestation and application of leadership competencies.  Throughout the course, an effort is also made to assist class members with strengthening selected leadership skills that can contribute to their professional effectiveness, career success, and general well-being.  To accomplish the learning goals of this course, varying instructional methodologies will be employed--including, lectures, cases, experiential exercises, self-assessments/reflection, and discussion.

Prerequisites:  MANA 30153 with a grade of at least C or concurrent enrollment, and must be a declared business major.  This course is intended to enhance students' ability to think critically and to apply this thinking to solving meaningful organizational problems--particularly the ambiguous strategic and leadership problems that managers frequently face.  Students will practice identifying problems in organizations and working to analyze key factors in order to provide solutions.  Specific attention will be given to issues such as problem identification, distinguishing reliable and unreliable information, spotting flawed arguments and constructing persuasive ones, awareness of cognitive biases and unwarranted assumptions, and how to research, develop, and present viable solutions.

Prerequisites:  ECON 10223.  Must be a business minor or receive departmental approval; completion of ACCT 20653 or concurrent enrollment.  Students may not receive credit for both MANA 30653 and MANA 30153.  Survey of Management is a required course within the business school minor that exposes students to the basic knowledge and skills that future managers will need to be effective.  A student in this course will learn about the environment of business and the issues facing modern managers and employees such as how to engage in effective decision making, planning, and strategic processes that help guide organizations; how to best organize and manage organizations for maximum effectiveness; how to lead and motivate employees and how to work in teams.

Prerequisites: Sophomore standing; must be a declared Business minor, or receive permission of the department.  The course will provide students with foundational experience in countries with emerging economies.  The goal is to provide understanding of how to do business in countries with emerging economies and how businesses operate in the base of the pyramid.  Specific attention will be provided to the culture of entrepreneurship. This course is not intended for Business majors.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript will be included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite: Departmental permission, and must be a declared Business major.  Preparation for and completion of a departmental honors project in the student's area of concentration in business under the direction of an assigned faculty member.  May be taken for up to three credit hours.

3 hours. Prerequisite: Senior standing, declared Business major, MANA 30153 or MANA 30253, MARK 30153, FINA 30153, and INSC 30313. Students are strongly encouraged to enroll in this class during their final two semesters before graduation.  This is the final integrating course for the senior business student. The policies and problems of management with respect to coordination of production, finance, marketing, human resources and accounting in a going concern under conditions of uncertainty.

Prerequisite: MANA 30153 with a grade of at least C or concurrent enrollment,  and must be a declared Business major.  The study of how organizations align HR and people management practices with business strategy to gain competitive advantage.  Explores techniques and topics that contribute to an effective work system, including: job design, planning and recruitment, selection, training and development, team-based systems, compensation and incentives, turnover, workforce analytics, and employment law.

Prerequisites:  BUSI 30843 with a grade of at least C for students in the BNSF Neeley Leadership Program.  For others, MANA 30153 with a grade of at least C, and must be a business major.  Modern organizational work frequently takes place within the boundaries of teams of various types (face-to-face, virtual, or hybrid teams).  Understanding how teams function and how best to manage them has become vitally important for successful leadership.  The purpose of this course is to expose students to and provide opportunities for them to apply practical knowledge of team dynamics.  Emphasis is placed on how to create a team environment and lead a team to promote creativity, psychological safety, cohesion, permission to fail and learn, and inclusivity.  Students in this class will also utilize a framework such as design thinking or systems thinking in a team environment to understand and solve problems.

3 hours. Prerequisite: MANA 30153 with a grade of at least C, and must be a declared Business major.  In an increasingly interconnected world, companies find themselves on the one hand forced to contend with a host of new competitors, but on the other hand facing a broad range of new opportunities for expansion abroad.  This course addresses both the pitfalls and opportunities that await mangers tasked with setting a direction for their organizations in this changing environment.

Prerequisites:  1.5 hours. Sophomore standing and must be a business major. Corequisite: Concurrent enrollment in MANA 30250 is required. This course covers essentials of Strategy, including internal and external analysis, business and external strategy, and strategic leadership.  Students are strongly encouraged to take this course early in their program to get an overview of topics associated with the Management major and Leadership Minor.

Prerequisites:  MANA 30153 and 30323 (with a grade of at least C in both), FINA 30153 (concurrent enrollment in FINA 30153 is acceptable), and must be a declared business major.  Concurrent enrollment in MANA 30323 is not allowed.  Managers and consultants are commonly called upon to solve complex problems that require them to possess a unique set of skills.  Specifically, they must be able to identify and assess problems, research available options, and create and propose possible solutions.  This course introduces the research skills needed to address complex organizational problems.  It also introduces practice of consultancy and gives students opportunities to apply their skills in realistic consulting contexts.

Prerequisites:  MANA 30153 with a grade of at least C, and must be a declared business major; permission of department required for non-business majors.  Diversity--be it gender, cultural, racial, or some other form--is pervasive in modern workplaces.  Successful leaders must operate within this diversity, overcoming the challenges that can occur when coordinating people with different perspectives and experiences, but also reaping the rewards of those differences (e.g., creativity and innovation).  This course examines leadership skills at the intersection of diversity and business.  Students will explore how diversity impacts leaders' and employees' perceptions and behaviors, and in turn, how these shape important individual and organizational outcomes.  The course will also look at how organizations can meet the needs of diverse employees and other stakeholders.

3 hours.  Prerequisites: MANA 30153 with a grade of C, and must be a Business major.  Study of distributive and integrative/principled methods of negotiation in interpersonal and intraorganizational contexts.  Includes such topics as negotiation strategies, tactics, preparation, social structure, power, ethics, coalition building, and multi-party and international negotiations.  Conflict resolution techniques that incorporate negotiation (such as mediation) will also be covered.

3 hours.  Prerequisites: permission of instructor is required, must be a declared Business major. The objective of the class is to expose students to different aspects of entrepreneurship, leadership, management, and business legal issues from an international perspective.  The course provides the opportunity to study variations in business practices and experience distinct cultures in stark clarity in an international setting.  Students will have the opportunity to experience topically relevant practices, for example by visiting local firms and interacting with business people in order to obtain a firsthand understanding of the impact of global influences.  This course may be repeated for credit.

3 hours.  Prerequisites: MANA 30153 with a least a grade of C, and must be a declared Business major.  This course addresses ethical conduct and social responsibility in organizations.  A multi-level approach to ethical decision-making is explored.  Students will apply individual, managerial, and organizational analyses to ethical dilemmas faced in the conduct of business.
Prerequisite:  Must be a declared business major. (1-6 semester hours) This course may be repeated for credit.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

3 hours. Prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MARK 30153; INSC 20153, and must be a declared Business major.   Obtaining market information; orientation in use of information gathered; role of management in initiating market studies and in defining problems; types of research; research design; questionnaire construction; sampling; analysis; motivation research; and product research.

3 hours. Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, and must be a Business major.   Students may not receive credit for both MARK 30153 and MARK 30653.  The processes in our society by which needs and wants of consumers are anticipated and satisfied. An examination of a systems approach to and analysis of the movement of goods from the point of production to the point of consumption.

Prerequisite: Grade of C- or higher in MARK 30153, a grade of C- or higher in MARK 30113, and must be a declared Business major.  To expose students to the analytical applications underlying many of the strategic marketing tools discussed at a conceptual level in lower-level marketing courses.  The course will be taught from the perspective of the marketing tool such as segmentation, with students' learning the relevant data analysis application, such as cluster analysis, to execute the marketing activity.  In addition to working through the analysis, analysis interpretation and relating results and recommendations to marketing management (i.e., decision makers) will also be covered.

Prerequisites: Grade of 'C-' or higher in MARK 30153; must be a declared Business major.  The most complex aspect of marketing is understanding the mind and heart of the consumer.  If consumer behavior was easy to explicate, then all products would sell as well as projected, all ads would be effective, economies would be efficient, and marketing would be a simple prospect.  In actuality, consumers are frustrating and irrational and difficult to predict.  This course focuses on providing you with the basic tools to gain insights into consumer behavior.

Prerequisites: MARK 30153 with a grade of C- or higher and be a declared business major.  Sports and Entertainment Marketing will build upon a marketing knowledge base and provide an overview of the issues faced by marketing managers both inside the sports and entertainment industry and outside the industry from firms that market through sports and entertainment.  Students will introduced to the unique qualities of the sports product and also examine the promotion mix, pricing, and distribution issues as they relate to the sports industry.

Prerequisites:  MARK 30153, must be a declared business major or permission of instructor or MABD student group.  Design thinking, or user centered design, is a framework for effective and creative problem solving.  In this course, students apply the framework to the creation of products, services and ideas through various design challenges.

Prerequisites:  Must be either a) a business minor with completion of ECON 10223 and completion or concurrent enrollment in  ACCT 20653 or b) admitted to the consultative selling certificate program or c) a Nutrition major with completion of ECON10223. Students may not receive credit for both MARK 30153 and MARK 30653. This course introduces the theory and practice of marketing, including the basic structure of getting products/services to market; the fundamentals of marketing: consumer research, product planning, promotion of all types, distribution channels, pricing, and retail merchandising.  The content will focus on marketing activities in consumer, reseller, industrial, government, and service markets.  This course is not for business majors.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisite: Departmental permission, and must be a declared Business major; Preparation for and completion of a departmental honors project in the student's area of concentration in business under the direction of an assigned faculty member.  May be taken for up to three credit hours.

Prerequisites: A grade of 'C-' or higher in MARK 30153 and must be a declared business major; a grade of 'C-' or higher, or concurrent enrollment in both MARK 30113 and MARK 30243.  As more money gets shifted away from traditional media and into digital and social media marketing, it is important that students understand how digital and social media marketing gets integrated into marketing strategy, branding, and integrated marketing communication concepts.  Broadly, digital marketing refers to everything that an organization does online to support its business.  This can include display advertising, social media, social media monitoring, search engine optimization and search engine marketing and other emerging ones as they develop.  However, the primary objective will be to examine: (1) driving business with digital marketing, (2) linking strategy to tactics, and (3) measuring outcomes and results.

Prerequisites:  A grade of 'C-' or higher in MARK 30153 and must be a business major; a grade of 'C-' or higher in MARK 30113 (Marketing Research) and a grade of 'C-' or higher or concurrent enrollment in MARK 30243 (Customer Insights).  This course focuses on the dynamic integration of artificial intelligence and automation in modern marketing. The course explores the powerful synergy between cutting-edge AI technologies and innovative marketing practices. During this course, we will cover both theoretical knowledge and hands-on applications, guiding students through the multifaceted world of AI-driven marketing, from the fundamentals of automation to advanced applications of machine learning in marketing strategy. It will equip you with the necessary knowledge and skills to harness these technologies to revolutionize customer engagement and drive business growth in today's data-driven landscape.

3 hours. Prerequisites: A grade of C- or higher in MARK 30153 and must be a declared business major; a grade of C- or higher in MARK 30113 (Marketing Research) and a grade of C- or higher or concurrent enrollment in MARK 30243 (Customer Insights).  The course is designed to provide a cohesive understanding of marketing from a managerial perspective through the exploration of marketing problems (using case analysis and other methods) via qualitative and quantitative analysis of the situation, integrative marketing program evaluation and planning, and marketing implementation recommendations. Must have senior standing.

3 hours. Prerequisites:  A grade of C- or higher in MARK 30153 and must be a declared business major.  This course introduces the field of international marketing and provides a broad perspective from which to explore and examine various aspects of what changes when firms compete internationally. Half the course focuses on unique aspects of the international marketing environment; half concentrates on how the marketing mix is affected by the globalization of markets and competitors.

Prerequisites: A grade of C- or higher in MARK 30153 and must be a declared business major.  The primary objective of this course is to prepare students to be able to successfully design and deliver exceptional service experiences in an increasingly service-oriented economy.  The course is designed to help students understand the unique characteristics of services, the marketing, people, and process challenges created by these characteristics, and effective ways to address these challenges to create differentiated customer value.

Prerequisites: A grade of C- or higher in MARK 30153 and must be a declared business major; a grade of C- or higher or concurrent enrollment in MARK 30243 (Customer Insights).  Course explores the strategic, organizational, process, and implementation issues involved in coordinating multiple forms of communications and media used for marketing campaigns--traditional advertising, direct marketing, interactive, public relations, sales promotion, personal selling, event marketing, and every other contact point with a target market.

Prerequisites: A grade of C- or higher in MARK 30153 and must be a declared business major; a grade of C- or higher in MARK 30113 (Marketing Research) and a grade of C- or higher or concurrent enrollment in MARK 30243 (Customer Insights).  Companies must continuously develop and bring to the market new and improved products.  We will study new product planning and management of both goods and services.  New Product planning and management of the product Portfolio are essential activities in all companies, and involve various business functions and external partners.  We look at the concepts and applications involved in managing an organization's brand portfolio.  An understanding of new product planning and brand portfolio management is an essential capability for many positions in business.

Prerequisites: A grade of C- or higher in MARK 30153 or 30653.  Must be a declared business major or admitted to the consultative selling certificate program.  There are several learning objectives for students in Foundations of Selling.  Primary to the course is the student's mastery of communication and presentation skills in the interpersonal and formal speaking environments.  One part of the course covers the text materials providing the student with a background in the fundamental aspects of persuasive communications, overcoming objections, and presentation planning.  Once these topics are mastered, the student then executes a persuasive and formal sales presentation, which is videotaped and critiqued.  Also, this course is designed to provide an understanding of the sales process and its role in business (and non-business) organizations and society.  The student is expected to acquire a working knowledge of sales concepts and terminology pertinent to the field.  You will explore the nature of the sales process and its functions, including presentation strategy, informative delivery, closing techniques, and an exploration of the various opportunities in sales as a career.  We will also cover areas such as personal attire, speaking skills, and interpersonal transactions.   Your most important assignment in this class is to sell yourself- and to do that you must believe in the product.

Prerequisites: Grade of 'C-' or higher in MARK 30153 or 30653. Grade of 'B' or higher in MARK 40263. Must be a declared business major or admitted to the consultative selling certificate program.  This class will seek to prepare students more fully for excellence in an entry-level professional selling position.  Specifically, students will gain advanced instruction and skill development in interpersonal communication skills (especially in team selling situations), career management, personal productivity, negotiation, and coordination with other functional areas.  One and a half hour lecture and one and a half hour laboratory period per week.

Prerequisites:  1.5 credits  Departmental permission.  MARK 40273 or MARK 40263 or current enrollment in either.  May be repeated one time for credit.  The sales practicum requirement combines practical sales experience and sales education.  Students will participate in a series of out-of-class, experiential learning activities that include shadowing salespeople and sales managers, on-site visiting of sales organizations, participating in sales competitions, participating in live selling activities, attending sales-related events or presentations, networking with sales professionals, and interviewing sales professionals.

1-3 hours. Prerequisites: A grade of "C-" or higher in MARK 30153 and must be a declared business major; a grade of "C-" or higher in MARK 30113 (Marketing Research) and a grade of "C-" or higher or concurrent enrollment in MARK 30243 (Customer Insights).  This course may be repeated for credit.
General Transfer Credit MTH TCU-CC
General Transfer Credit

A selection of topics of general interest and some degree of applicability, such as apportionment, voting methods, graph theory, tilings and polyhedra, mathematics of finance, probability, and statistics.  Students are expected to have mathematical background equivalent to college algebra or two years of high school algebra and one year of geometry.

Empirical frequency distributions, binomial and normal distributions. Regression and correlation. Statistical inference.  Students are expected to have mathematical background equivalent to college algebra or two years of high school algebra. 
Students may not receive credit for both MATH 10043 and INSC 20153.

Precalculus treatment of polynomial, rational, exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions with particular emphasis on topics needed for MATH 10524. 
Students are expected to have mathematical background equivalent to college algebra or two years of high school algebra and one year of geometry.  Notes: Credit will not be given for both MATH 10273 and MATH 10054.  This course does not satisfy the Core Curriculum's Mathematical Reasoning requirement.
General Transfer Credit

Precalculus treatment of polynomial, rational, exponential and logarithmic functions. Additional special applications from the mathematics of finance and probability. 
Students are expected to have mathematical background equivalent to college algebra or two years of high school algebra.  Notes: Credit will not be given for both MATH 10054 and MATH 10273.  This course does not satisfy the Core Curriculum's Mathematical Reasoning requirement.

Prerequisite: MATH 10273 with a grade of C- or better, or MATH 10054 with a grade of C- or better, or a score of at least 3 on the AP Precalculus exam, or a score of at least 600 on the SAT Math exam, or a score of at least 24 on the ACT Math exam, or a passing score on the Applied Calculus Placement Test (after receiving a grade less than C- in MATH 10273, the Calculus Placement Test cannot be used to satisfy the prerequisite).  The elements of calculus, with applications to business and economics. 
Students are expected to have mathematical background equivalent to college algebra or two years of high school algebra.  Notes: Credit will not be given for both MATH 10283 and MATH 10524.

Prerequisite: MATH 10054 with a grade of C- or better, or AP Calculus AB or BC score of 3 or better, or a passing grade on the Calculus Placement Test (after receiving a grade less than C- in MATH 10054, the Calculus Placement Test cannot be used to satisfy the prerequisite).  Differential and integral calculus of elementary functions, including exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions. Applications. 
Note: credit will not be given for both MATH 10283 and MATH 10524.

Prerequisites: Completion of the Core curriculum Mathematical Reasoning requirement.  A mathematics content course for EC-6 Education Majors.  The basic foundations of mathematics will be stressed in the development of problem-solving skills and an understanding of the operations and properties of the real number system and basic topics in geometry.  Note: this course may not be counted toward a major or minor in Mathematics, nor does it satisfy the core mathematical reasoning requirement.

Prerequisites: completion of the Core Curriculum Mathematical Reasoning requirement.  A mathematics content course for Middle School Mathematics Education Majors.  Topics will be selected from: an introduction to mathematical reasoning, sets, relations and functions, development of the real number system, systems of enumeration, change of base, elementary number theory.  Note: May not be counted toward a major or minor in mathematics.  This course does not satisfy the core mathematical reasoning requirement.

Prerequisite: Completion of the Core Curriculum Mathematical Reasoning requirement.  A mathematics content course for Middle School Mathematics Majors.  Topics will be selected from: an introduction to the geometry of polygons, circles, polyhedra and spheres, transformations, similarity, constructions, measurement, coordinate geometry, networks, logic.  Note: may not be counted toward a major or minor in mathematics.  This course does not satisfy the core mathematical reasoning requirement.

Prerequisite: MATH 10054 or 10273 or 10283 or MATH 10524 with a grade of C- or better; or a score of at least 600 on the SAT Math exam; or a score of at least 24 on the ACT Math exam.  An introduction to discrete methods used in mathematics and computer science. Topics covered include formal logic, sets, the principle of inclusion-exclusion, functions, proof techniques including mathematical induction, number theory, and algorithms.  Students are expected to have mathematical background equivalent to college or high school precalculus.
Prerequisite: MATH 10524 with a C- or better. Techniques of integration and applications. Infinite series. Differential equations as time permits.
1 - 3 semester hours.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor and department.  This course is intended for students pursuing Honors research.  1.00-3.00 credits.

Prerequisites:  Math 20123 and 20524, both with a C- or
better.  Mathematical proof in the context of algebra and analysis.

Prerequisites:  COSC 20803 and MATH 20123 with a C- or better in both. Essential elements of the data science lifecycle from theory to practice.  Introduces fundamental skills to prepare for advanced study in data science.  Methodologies and several open source tools used in solving data science problems are studied.  (Cross-listed as COSC/MATH 30103.)
Prerequisite: MATH 20123 with a C- or better. Continuation of MATH 20123.  Topics covered include combinatorics, recurrence relations, equivalence relations, graphs and trees.

Prerequisite: MATH 10524 and either MATH 20123 or MATH 20524, all with a C- or better. Vector spaces, linear independence, bases, and dimension. Linear mappings, matrices, and determinants. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization.

Prerequisite: MATH 20524 with a C- or better. Vector calculus and multiple integration. Optimization and Lagrange multipliers. Vector fields and potential functions. Gradient, curl, and divergence. Line and surface integrals. The theorems of Green, Stokes, and Gauss, as time permits.

Prerequisite: MATH 20524 with a C- or better  and successful completion of the Excel Expert 1 portion of the MOS test.   A rigorous development of the theory of interest in both discrete and continuous time.  Present value, yield rates, compound interest, amortization, and cash flows.  Selected financial applications to bonds and securities.
Prerequisite: MATH 20524 with a C- or better. Solution techniques for ordinary differential equations. Systems of differential equations. Mathematical modeling and applications.

Prerequisites: MATH 30603 with C- or better.  Treatment of bonds and yield rates, stocks and financial markets, arbitrage, the term structure of interest rates, options and swaps, and topics in interest rate sensitivity including duration, convexity and immunization.

Prerequisite: MATH 20524 with a C- or better. Probability theory. Permutations, combinations, elementary probability, and the binomial theorem.  Discrete and continuous probability distributions in single variable and joint variable settings.

Prerequisites: MATH 20524 with a C- or better.  Organization and analysis of data.  Descriptive statistics.  Confidence intervals and hypothesis testing.  As time permits, topics in regression, analysis of variance, nonparametric statistics, sampling methods.
Prerequisites:  Department permission. Non-research independent study.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor and department. This course is intended forstudents pursuing directed research. It may be repeated for credit.Credits: 1.00-3.00

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit. The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor and department.  This course is intended for students writing an undergraduate thesis in Mathematics or Actuarial Science.1.00-3.00 Credits

Prerequisites:  Math 30224 with a C- or better.
Graphs, directed graphs and their representations, weighted graphs, shortest path, Hamiltonian and Eulerian circuits, spanning trees, matching connectedness, flows, Euler's formula, planarity, duality, polyhedra coloring theorems with applications to map coloring and scheduling problems.  Ramsey theory, enumeration and random walks, if time allows..

Prerequisites:  MATH 30224 with a C- or better, and competence in high-level programming language.Vector spaces and bases, linear transformations and operators, Jordan canonical form of a matrix, inner products, Hermitian and unitary operators.  Numerical methods.  Topics selected from Fourier series and transforms, applications to ordinary and partial differential equations, applications to Markov processes.

Prerequisite: MATH 30053 and 30524 both with C- or better.  Topological spaces, bases, connectedness, compactness.  Continuous functions and homeomorphisms.  Separation properties.  Product and quotient spaces.  Metric spaces.

Prerequisites: MATH 20524 with a grade of 'C-' or better.  Classical geometric constructions.  The basic concepts of Euclidean Geometry and analytic geometry.  An introduction to non-Euclidean geometry as time permits.  Geometry software applications for each of these topics.

Prerequisites:  MATH 30224, 30524 and 30613, all with a C- or better.  
Fourier series and Fourier transform, discrete Fourier transform and numerical methods, convolution, signal processing, filtering wavelet analysis.

Prerequisites: MATH 30524 and 30803, both with a C- or better and successful completion of the Excel Expert 1 portion of the MOS test.  Applications of calculus, probability, and statistics, emphasizing problems in risk management and insurance.

Prerequisites: 2.75 GPA in major, completion of either MATH 30603 or MATH 40603, and approval of department chair.  Practical experience in the actuarial field.  Must include a minimum of 90 work hours in an approved practical experience situation.  This course may only be taken pass/no credit and may be repeated up to a total of 3 credit hours.
Prerequisite:  MATH 30613 with a C- or better.  Dynamical systems on the line and on the circle, bifurcations, flows, attractors, linearization, applications to physics, biology, and engineering.

Prerequisites:  MATH 30224, 30524 and 30803, all with a C- or better.
Sequential move games, game trees, perfect information games and games of chance.  Matrix games, dominated and mixed strategies, the mini-max theorem.  Continuous games, games of timing.  Multi-player games and Nash equilibrium, cooperative games:  core and stable sets, bargaining, nucleolus.  If time permits, special topics can include linear programming, side payments, power indices, imperfect information and artificial intelligence.

Prerequisite: MATH 20524 and 30224 both with C- or better, and competence in a high-level programming language.  Introduction to numerical methods for solving mathematical problems that arise in the sciences.  Topics include floating point arithmetic, error analysis, interpolation, approximating solutions to nonlinear equations, numerical integration and differentiation, and other selected topics.

Prerequisites:  At least five Mathematics courses counting toward a Mathematics major with at least a 2.75 GPA in these courses and approval of Department Chair.  Students must spend at least 90 hours in approved practical work experience.  This course may only be taken pass/no credit and is repeatable up to a total of 3 credit hours.

Prerequisites:  MATH 30224 and 30853, both with a C- or better.  Topics include assessing normality of data, simple & multivariable linear regression, model checking diagnostics, variable selection, trends & seasonality in time series, and autoregressive-moving-average (ARMA) models.  Additional topics may include forecasting, models for count outcome data, and the generalized linear model.

Prerequisites:  MATH 30224 and 30853, both with a C- or better.  Topics will include methods and tools for predictive modeling, including data pre-processing, bias-variance trade-off and model tuning, and analysis techniques including linear regression, adaptive and nearest-neighbor methods, rule-based models, and classification models.
Prerequisite:  Permission of the instructor. 1 - 6 semester hours.

Prerequisites: MATH 20524 with a C- or better.  A survey of the history of mathematics from ancient times to contemporary times.  The selection of topics may vary from semester to semester, but topics closely related to contemporary mathematics are usually emphasized.
Prerequisites: MATH 30053 and 30224, both with a C- or better. Introduction to groups and rings. Homomorphisms, isomorphisms, subgroups, and ideals. Quotient and product structures.
Prerequisites: MATH 30224 and 30524, both with a C- or better.  Calculus on Euclidean space.  Geometry of curves and surfaces.

Prerequisites: MATH 30524 with a C- or better.  Analytic functions, harmonic functions, and the Cauchy-Riemann equations.  Conformal mappings.  Cauchy's integral theorem and formula, with applications.  Power series and analytic continuation.
Prerequisites: MATH 30053 with a C- or better.  A rigorous development of elementary limit processes. Continuity, sequences, series, differentiation, integration.
Prerequisites: MATH 30613 and 30524, both with a C- or better. Basic theory of hyperbolic, parabolic, and elliptic partial differential equations.
Prerequisites: MATH 20123 and 30224, both with a C- or better. Properties of the integers. Divisibility, prime numbers, modular arithmetic, Chinese Remainder Theorem, Diophantine equations.

Fall/Spring.  One class per week.  This course facilitates the development of leadership skills while giving practical experience in military skills.  Areas of emphasis include drill and ceremonies, squad level tactics, first aid and land navigation.  Advanced Course cadets conduct the training and lead the cadet battalion under cadre supervision.  A weekend field training exercise and weekly physical fitness training are included in the course.

Fall. One class per week. A progressive overview of the U.S. Army to include its history, its organization, its customs and courtesies, its strategic mission, dynamic structure, and methods of tactical deployment. Included is a field trip, where students are exposed to on- and off-duty Army life and have the opportunity to observe new combat arms lieutenants in action.

Spring. One class per week. Fundamentals of basic tactics to include movement techniques, battle drill/assault techniques, squad tactical control measures, land navigation, and first-aid training. Designed to give the student an initial level of tactical proficiency and a degree of leadership training.
MILS Transfer Credit.

Fall. One class per week. Challenges the student to become tactically and technically proficient. Students study the military element of power, learn and practice first aid, use light infantry tactics, and gain a fundamental knowledge of map reading. Prerequisite: Concurrent or past enrollment in MILS 10041 or permission of the department chair.

Spring. One class per week. This course prepares students to be positive and assertive leaders and conduct instruction through the study and application of basic military leadership principles. Includes leadership assessment training and student classroom presentations. Prerequisite: Concurrent or past enrollment in MILS 10041 Introduction to Military Science or permission of the department chair.
Fall/Spring. Special study opportunities as directed by the Department Chairman. (1-6 semester hours.)

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Fall.  One class per week. Students learn effective counseling, writing, and human relation skills necessary to positively influence human behavior. Students develop confidence and leadership experience in addition to land navigation skills and tactical proficiency. Group participation and exposure to leadership reaction situations. Prerequisite: Basic Course or equivalent credit.

Spring. One class per week. An analysis of the leader's role in directing and coordinating the efforts of individuals and organizations. This professional block of instruction involves student role modeling and analysis of controversial leadership case situations. Students practice and learn the necessary skills to take charge when responsible, as well as control and positively influence personnel under stressful situations. Additional professional skills are also taught. Prerequisite: Completion of MILS 30053 or permission of department chair.
Fall/Spring. Opportunity for independent study as directed by the instructor prior to enrollment. (1-6 semester hours)

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Fall. One class per week. Designed to review the mission and structure of the Army as well as discuss its professional and social aspects. The course focuses on oral and written communication skills, counseling techniques, evaluation, and reporting procedures, as well as introducing the combined arms concept. Prerequisite: Completion of MILS 30053 and 30063 or permission of department chair.

Spring. One class per week. An examination of the dynamics of modern warfare from the perspective of the combat battalion task force. The integration of maneuver forces, air power, intelligence, logistics, and air mobility by a ground combat commander is studied in both practical exercise and case studies. A variety of other subjects relating to staff procedures and command and control are covered. Prerequisite: Completion of MILS 30053 and 30063 or permission of department chair.

In this class, students seek to understand definitions of the term cosmopolitanism in its various inflections. Students will interrogate those inflections and discuss them in association with concepts such as nationalism, humanism, globalization, global ethics, and identity. Analyzing cultural products from around the world, students will ask questions such as the following: What does it mean to be a global citizen? What role does language play in how we envision global citizenship? What does it mean to think of someone as "the other" and how is that related to one's own "otherness"? How do/can we accommodate national identities and global citizenship?
Student is studying abroad this semester with a Partner Program.

Prerequisite: Junior standing.  Survey of major areas of linguistics: sound systems, language universals, and language in society as well as an introduction to psycholinguistics and how the brain processes language.

Prerequisite:  A fourth semester language class or equivalent proficiency level as established by departmental faculty, as well as the agreement of a full-time faulty partner to mentor for two Annotated Translation projects.  In this course, you will gain some hands-on experience with translation from your language of study (Chinese, French, German, or Italian) to English.  We will also discuss principles and theories of the skill/art/profession of translation.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisites:  Any 3xxxx level Chinese, English, French, German or Italian course.  The senior seminar course is designed to guide students as they shape a culminating project that synthesizes and creatively engages the linguistic, cultural, and the theoretical knowledge they have been developing over the course of their studies.  The course will focus on a specific theme that crosses language disciplines, and that theme will be explored and analyzed in at least three different language contexts in class assignments and discussions, but students will develop their final projects in their own language area.
General Transfer Credit TCUCC-FAR credit.
Rudiments of music including notation, intervals, scales, harmony, and form.
Wind Symphony.
Percussion Ensemble.
Elementary techniques of playing and teaching guitar for music education majors.
The Field Guide to Italian Music and Culture:  Then and Now will concentrate on music history in Rome and Florence and its influence on culture in the past and present.

The Choral Union is a non-auditioned ensemble open to all members of the TCU community.  Weekly rehearsals will focus on vocal, musical and ensemble development.  The ensemble is designed to accommodate singers of all abilities.  0.5 hours credit per semester.
An introduction to the history of jazz, focusing on its role in U.S. history and culture.
Concert Chorale.

An introduction of music theory for the non-Music Major.  Music notation, the piano keyboard, scales, key signatures, rhythm, chords/7th chords, and diatonic harmony will be introduced, with application being proved in the writing of melodies and simple pieces of music.  Students will learn of the universality of the language of music by influences from around the world throughout history, as well as see the application of these music fundamentals in the music they hear every day.  Use of music technology will include an online theory program and an online music notation program.
The purpose of this course is to provide percussion students with rehearsal and performance experience within a steel band setting.
Elementary techniques of playing and teaching violin, viola, cello, and bass for music education and composition majors.
An introduction to the history of art music in Western culture, exploring both musical styles and sociocultural functions. Not available to music majors or minors for degree credit.
Prerequisite: Must be a vocal music education major or have permission of instructor through an audition.

Prerequisite: MUSI 10051 or demonstrated proficiency on a string instrument as approved by the instructor. Continuation of elementary techniques of playing and teaching violin, viola, cello, and bass for music education and composition majors.
An introduction to the variety of musics found in cultures around the world outside the Western art music tradition. Not available to music majors for degree credit.
Vocal Jazz Ensemble.
Elementary techniques of playing and teaching percussion instruments for music education majors.
An introduction to rock and popular music in the United States from 1945 onward. Emphasis is placed on the sequential development of substantive listening and descriptive skills.
Chamber Music.
Introduction to string, brass, woodwind and percussion instructional techniques for vocal concentration music education majors.

An introduction to the history and aesthetics of the cinematic soundtrack. Through lecture, discussion, reading, and listening, students will examine the evolution of film music, its composers, and their musical styles. Students will also study the different elements of music, and how film composers use them to support and
enhance the film narrative.
Woodwind Ensemble.

Prerequisite: must be a Music major.  This course is a pass/no credit course.  The course focuses on flexibility, balance, strength, and relaxation.  Using postures and breathing exercises adapted to each person's individual level, students will develop improved alignment, breathing, and a balanced body/mind.  Students will unite these elements to aid in performance anxiety, posture, phrasing, and other activities inherent to their particular instrument.  Limited discussion may include ways to incorporate yoga techniques into the students' daily activities, particularly in practice, rehearsal, and performance.  This class is designed to accommodate both those who are new to yoga practice, as well as those with some experience.

Prerequisite:  Permission of the instructor is required through an audition.  Exploration of the preparation and presentation of operatic and music theatre repertoire for an audience. Students enhance their knowledge of singing, acting, movement, stagecraft, and technical theatre throughout the semester.
Marching Band.
Symphony Orchestra.

The TCU Cantiamo (Women's Choir) is an ensemble dedicated to performance of quality treble repertoire.  Majors and non-majors are encouraged to participate.  No audition is required for participation.  The ensemble performs a minimum of two concerts per semester.

Frog Corps is a non-auditioned male ensemble that serves as a spirit group for the university campus.  Performances include traditional concerts with other university ensembles, appearances at athletic events, and presentation at university and community social occasions.
The ensemble performs mixed chamber music primarily composed during the past 25 years.
Brass Ensemble.
Undergraduate Collaborative Piano
Introduction to the International Phonetic Alphabet and its application to the study of Liturgical Latin, Italian, and English lyric diction.
Collegium Musicum.
Prerequisite: MUSI 10171 or permission of instructor. Application of International Phonetic Alphabet to the study of German and French lyric diction.
Jazz Ensemble.
A study of the techniques of jazz improvisation through performance. May be repeated for maximum of 4 hours credit.
General Transfer Credit
Melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic dictation; sight-singing.

Prerequisite:  MUSI 10003 or placement via AP Exam or School of Music Theory Exam.  Musical notation and definitions, intervals, scales and keys. Emphasis on writing four-voice exercises in major and minor keys using triads and dominant sevenths. Harmonic analysis.
Symphonic Band.
Prerequisite: MUSI 10201. Continuation of MUSI 10201.

Prerequisite: MUSI 10203. Continuation of MUSI 10203, including study of suspensions and other non-chord tones, the remaining diatonic seventh chords and secondary functions. Harmonic analysis, as well as study of cadences, phrases and periods. Keyboard harmony.

The Concert Band provides students from all academic disciplines with a creative and positive music-making environment with a limited rehearsal schedule.  A wide range of musical styles is offered, and opportunities are provided for music majors to develop on their secondary instruments.
Fundamentals of music performance, composition and listening. Appropriate for elementary education majors. Not open to music majors and minors.
The purpose of this course is to provide percussion students with rehearsal and performance experience within a steel band setting.

Prerequisites:  Music major/minor or permission of instructor. All students enrolled in a mariachi course must be able to play an instrument; therefore, vocalists will be asked to learn a mariachi-based instrument if they do not know how to play one already.

Practical, comprehensive introduction to all aspects of accompanying a wide variety of vocal and instrumental music. Main topics include development of sight reading and ensemble skills, techniques for rehearsing and working with others in performance, and general concepts of the philosophy of performance.
Performers Certificate Collaborative Piano II
The purpose of this course is to provide percussion students with rehearsal and performance experience within a percussion ensemble setting.
Study and performance of music for cello ensemble
Prerequisites: Instructor's permission required.  The study and performance of music for harp ensemble.
Symphony Orchestra - Strings Only.  This course is for string players playing in Symphony Orchestra.  Winds, Brass, and Percussion should enroll in MUSI 10120.
Topics may vary each time it is offered.

This course is an introduction to a variety of facets of music teaching and pedagogy through observation, reading and discovery experiences.  Students will become acquainted with elements of learning and teaching.  Micro-teaching experiences will be provided.

Prerequisites: Acceptance in Bachelor of Music Education, Bachelor of Music, or Bachelor of Arts degree plan in Voice.  A systematic introduction to the multiple skill sets required of the effective vocal performer and exploration of artistic and practical aspects of the performer's world.

Music majors are required to attend a minimum of 15 concerts and recitals each semester, with the exception of the student-teaching semester for Music Education majors.  Six (6) of these concerts must be from the weekly School of Music Recital Hour Series.  The remainder may be chosen from faculty and guest artist recitals, TCU and guest ensemble concerts, and student recitals.  Students will submit original printed concert programs signed by a TCU School of Music faculty member in attendance.

This course activity is an important element in the development of critical listening skills.  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)

Introduction to Piano for the Non-Musician is a laboratory class which meets twice weekly, designed to teach beginning piano to the college-age student.  No previous experience with music or piano is necessary.  Classes meet in a piano laboratory setting.  The study of piano follows the School of Music mission to affirm music as an integral part of a classic liberal arts education.  Not available to music majors or minors for degree credit.
Beginning piano for non-keyboard music majors who are preparing to pass the basic piano requirement.  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)
Prerequisites: Completion of MUSI 11021 or permission of instructor.  Continuation of MUSI 11021.
Prerequisite: MUSI 11030. Continuation of MUSI 11030.  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)
Class instruction designed to train students in vocal technique and literature.

Prerequisite: Keyboard, Piano Pedagogy and Music Education piano concentration majors only; MUSI 10201, 10203, 10211, 10213 and two semesters 20201.  Functional keyboard skills for keyboard majors, including transposition, harmonization, score-reduction, improvisation
Prerequisite: MUSI 20071.  Continuation of MUSI 20071.

Prerequisite: Sophomore standing in music or permission of instructor. Intensive study of selected works of chamber music with piano. Emphasis on developing the musical and interactive skills needed for chamber music through rehearsal and performance. Weekly coaching with faculty.
Prerequisite: MUSI 20082 or permission of instructor.

Prerequisite: MUSI 10211. Increasingly difficult melodic and rhythmic dictation. Harmonic dictation including seventh chords and modulations. Sight-singing of single line, two-voice, and four-voice music.
Prerequisite: MUSI 10213. Modulatory techniques, simple binary and ternary forms, modal mixture, and chromatic chords. Harmonic analysis and compositional exercises. Keyboard harmony.
Prerequisite: MUSI 20201. Continuation of MUSI 20201.

Prerequisite: Sophomore standing in music or permission of instructor. A workshop class for pianists in which selected works of the piano literature are performed, analyzed and discussed. Special focus is on the etude and its development. Class members perform assigned works and present individual reports on topics relating to the music.

Prerequisite: MUSI 20203. Continuation of MUSI 20203, including tonal harmony in the late 19th century and an introduction to 20th century practice. Harmonic analysis and compositional exercises. Keyboard harmony.
An introduction to classroom teaching pedagogy, learning theory, planning, and assessment.

Prerequisite: MUSI 10203, 10213 and declared major or minor in theory/composition. Beginning compositional exercises in tonal genres with emphasis on basic chromatic usage in short keyboard, vocal, and rondo forms.

Prerequisite: MUSI 20203 and declared major or minor in theory/composition. Continuation of MUSI 20412. Compositional exercises in tonal genres with emphasis on advanced chromatic usage in short keyboard and vocal forms as well as in small chamber ensembles.

This course is a study and development of skills pertinent to choral pedagogy methods including score preparation; technical discernment; error detection; analysis of vocal tone, timbre, and production; musicianship; effective teaching strategies, and rehearsal techniques for the secondary choral classroom.  Lab Required.

Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, music major or permission of instructor. Conducting patterns, preparation, cues, release, and technical and expressive movements applicable to vocal and instrumental conductors.

Marching band methods, techniques, and design tools will be presented in a lecture format.  Each student will be given opportunity to teach and learn techniques that are presented as well as practice computer assisted design.

Prerequisite:  Successful completion of MUSI 20203 or permission of instructor.  This course is designed to help students understand the position of music in history, contributions to musical thought, and the development of musical style in Western culture to the mid-seventeenth century through a detailed study of music literature.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Prerequisite: MUSI 11040. Continuation of MUSI 11040.  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)
Prerequisite: MUSI 21030. Continuation of MUSI 21030.  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)

Prerequisite: Enrollment in the Artist Diploma Program.  Study and performance of advanced repertoire for the collaborative pianist, including accompaniment and chamber music.  Emphasis on developing the musical and interactive skills needed for collaborative playing through rehearsal, coaching, and performance.

Prerequisites:  Upper division standing (junior or senior) in vocal music education or permission from instructor.  This course is an introduction to vocal pedagogy and voice science.  Topics will include anatomy and physiology of the vocal mechanism, diagnosis and correction of vocal faults, acoustics, and technology in the classroom.  Supplemental seminars will provide practical experience with audio recording concepts and technologies.

Prerequisite: Junior standing in music and in piano. Introduction to methods, materials and techniques employed in the teaching of beginning piano students. Establishing and managing a piano studio public relations, equipment and layout, professional memberships, budget and tax information, studio policy and teacher-student-parent roles. Lecture and observation.

Prerequisite: MUSI 30052. Examines materials for the intermediate piano student method books, standard piano repertoire, theory and technique, jazz and ensemble works. Also focuses on practice motivation, recital preparation, and auditions, festivals and contests. Also deals with teaching preschool and adult beginners. Lecture and observation.

This course covers basic skills and concepts for playing and teaching the saxophone, oboe, and bassoon.  Emphasis will be placed on basic pedagogical techniques for each instrument towards an ability to teach at the beginner level.

This course covers basic skills and concepts for playing and teaching the trumpet and french horn.  Emphasis will be placed on basic pedagogical techniques for each instrument towards an ability to teach at the beginner level.

Corequisite:  Concurrent enrollment in MUSI 10100 Opera Studio is required.  Development of acting techniques to enhance the dramatic presentation of vocal music. Units include musical and text analysis, character development, focus choices, gestures, attitudes, dramatic arcs and interpretive methods for presenting sung repertoire in public settings..

This course covers basic skills and concepts for playing and teaching the flute and clarinet.  Emphasis will be placed on basic pedagogical techniques for each instrument towards an ability to teach at the beginner level.

This course covers basic skills and concepts for playing and teaching the trombone, euphonium, and tuba.  Emphasis will be placed on basic pedagogical techniques for each instrument towards an ability to teach at the beginner level.
Prerequisites: MUSI 20211, 20213. Structural analysis of simple and compound part forms, rondo, sonata and fugue. Emphasis on the standard designs found in instrumental music from Bach on.

Prerequisite: MUSI 20213. Counterpoint in the style of the 16th century including ecclesiastical modes, melodic structure, two-part exercises, three-part textures, cadences, paraphrase technique and canon.

Prerequisite: MUSI 20213. Counterpoint in the style of the 18th century including melodic structure, two-part texture, chromaticism, invertible counterpoint, two-part invention, three-part texture, imitation, three-part invention, the trio sonata, fugue, chorale and contrapuntal variation forms.

Prerequisites:  Junior standing as a BME student in the School of Music, or by permission of instructor.  In this course, students will learn fundamental skills and concepts for teaching jazz in the school setting, including standard notation and instrumentation, styles, improvisation, rehearsal techniques, repertoire, and programming considerations.  Students will learn the fundamentals of jazz theory, and will participate in and teach a lab ensemble as part of the class.
Prerequisites: MUSI 20211, 20213. Practical consideration of techniques, capabilities and effective uses of orchestral and band instruments in various combinations. Arranging and scoring.
Vocal and instrumental expression, rhythmic activities, critical listening, creative experience, and music reading. Course appropriate for pedagogy students.

Prerequisite: Open to Music Composition majors who have completed MUSI 30312 (Instrumentation), or by permission of instructor. Project-based application of concepts learned in MUSI 30312 to music arranging and composition.
Prerequisites: MUSI 20203/20213, 30312, or permission of instructor. Study in technique of scoring for the contemporary marching band.
Prerequisites: MUSI 20203/ 20213, 30312, or permission of instructor. Study in technique of scoring for the modern jazz orchestra.

Prerequisite: Music major or permission of instructor.  Through a project based curriculum students will explore the fundamental principles and techniques of electronic and electro-acoustic compositional techniques, synthesis, audio recording principles and techniques, the function and operation of music studio equipment including microphones, digital audio workstations, audio editing and effects software, synthesizers, mixers and MIDI devices.

Prerequisites:  Sophomore Level.  Any major.  An investigation of basic and electronic audio concepts, psychoacoustics, digital audio recording techniques, and synthesis.  Projects are produced with student owned computers utilizing microphones, connectors and interfaces provided by the university.  Students will demonstrate understanding of recording apparatus including, microphones, digital audio workstations, editing software, audio mixers and MIDI controllers.
Prerequisite: MUSI 20412 or permission of instructor. Advanced private study in composition. Primarily intended for composition majors. 1-10 semester hours.

Prerequisite: MUSI 20512. Technique of the baton, score reading, tone production, rehearsal routines, vocal materials, organization problems, supervised practice in conducting chorus. Meets choral conducting requirements for secondary school teachers.

Prerequisite: MUSI 20512. Instrumental conducting technique, score reading and analysis, supervised practice conducting ensembles. Meets instrumental conducting requirements for secondary school teachers. Lab required.

Prerequisites: Junior-level standing as a music major, or permission of instructor.  This course serves as an introduction for music majors to the variety of musics found in cultures around the world outside the Western art music tradition.

Music for Social Change will examine how the study of music and ensemble participation are used as a vehicle for social change with marginalized children living in low socio-economic communities.  Students will evaluate issues of race, gender, class, and trauma through the lenses of social leadership and artistic citizenship.  Students will develop instructional planning skills and classroom management techniques within a service-learning environment at an EL Sistema-inspired music education program.

Prerequisite:  Successful completion of MUSI 20613 or permission of instructor and completion of ENGL 10803 and 20803.   Exploration of musical genres, forms, composers, and styles in Europe and the New World from the mid-seventeenth to the late nineteenth century.

Prerequisite: Successful completion of MUSI 30613, ENGL 10803 and 20803.  Historical and cultural overview of trends in Western music from the late nineteenth century to the present, addressing topics including art music, jazz, and popular music.

Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  Organ and choral works in the church music program. Practical performance of anthems, motets, small cantatas.  Modulation and transposition.  Sacred wedding music.  Accompanying and sight reading.  Directing from the console.

Prerequisite: Junior standing. This course is a study of wind band pedagogy methods with emphasis on instrumental instructional techniques, effective teaching strategies, rehearsal techniques, comprehensive musicianship, classroom management, motivation, and administration of the secondary band program.  Lab required.

Prerequisite: MUSI 30812.  This course is a study of wind band pedagogy methods with emphasis on instrumental instructional techniques, effective teaching strategies, rehearsal techniques, comprehensive musicianship, classroom management, motivation, and administration of the secondary band program.  Lab required.

This course is a study of choral pedagogy methods with emphasis on vocal and choral techniques, effective teaching strategies, rehearsal techniques, comprehensive musicianship, classroom management, motivation, and administration the secondary choral program.  Lab required.

This course is a continuation of the study and development of choral pedagogy methods with emphasis on effective teaching strategies, rehearsal techniques, comprehensive musicianship, classroom management motivation, and administration in the secondary choral program.  Lab required.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  Specialized work in student's area of concentration. 1-6 Hours
