The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

Prerequisites: STCO 11103 or 21103 and STCO 16103 or 26103.  Strategic message creation with an emphasis on best practices for writing and editing in advertising and public relations.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: A grade of C or higher in each of the gateway courses STCO 23113 and 23123; and a combined GPA of 2.5 or higher in these courses; and a C- or higher in MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 or equivalent.  Introduction to page layout software, image editing and basics of design.  Creation and critique of designs for advertisements, newsletters and other printed and digital pieces.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: STCO 16103 and 32403.   The study of principles and techniques in digital photography and video in strategic communication with the goal of producing images for public relations and advertising.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite:  Prerequisites: STCO 11103 or 21103, STCO 16103 or 26103, STCO 32403, and STCO 35503.  Non-majors need permission of instructor.  Creation and critique of printed and digital publications.  Introduction to art direction, design theory, planning, production, printing, digital delivery, brand extension and visual continuity.   Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: STCO 11103 or 21103 and 32403.  Planning, creating and producing materials for advertising and public relations.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite:  A grade of C or higher in each of the gateway courses STCO 23113 and 23123; and a combined GPA of 2.5 or higher in these courses; and a C- or higher in MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 (Statistics) or equivalent.  Introduces qualitative and quantitative research methods and metrics commonly used in advertising and public relations.  The class emphasizes the use of research to shape decisions.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites:  STCO 11103 or 21103 and STCO 32403.  Introduction to video editing software, image editing and basics of digital storytelling.  Creation and critique of videos for advertisements, stories, and advocacy.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, 32403, and 35503.   The use of advertising, public relations and marketing principles to create social change by influencing people's attitudes and behavior.  Commonly used in public health communication, social marketing tackles societal problems needing behavioral change.  Introduces the field of transformative consumer research.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: STCO 11103, 16103, 32403, and 35503.  A major research study, generally offered to seniors in the major on an independent study basis, involving a substantial topic or project under the supervision of a three-member faculty committee.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites:  Acceptance in the Strategic Communication Washington Semester program and permission of the designated coordinator of the Washington Semester.  This colloquium, hosted by The Washington Center, promotes personal and professional growth in interns.  The colloquium exposes interns to persons and places relevant to their career goals, culminating in reflective analysis, deeper self-awareness, and a thorough understanding of their respective careers.  Required course for students in the Washington program.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites:  Acceptance in the Strategic Communication Washington Semester program and permission of the designated coordinator of the Washington Semester.  Practical experience overseen by a faculty member in a media organization in the Washington, D.C., area consistent with the student's major in Strategic Communication.  Credit hours are based on approximately 75 hours in internship activities for each semester credit hours.  A maximum of six credit hours can be applied toward the Strategic Communication major.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites:  Acceptance in the Strategic Communication Washington Semester program and permission of the designated Coordinator of the Washington Semester.  Studies issues related to government and communication in Washington D.C.  Topics may be related to legal or historical issues, lobbying, campaigning, public policy, research, or other issues, as approved by the Coordinator of the Washington Semester.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: Senior standing, with at least 18 hours in the major.  This course helps students identify their strengths, competencies, skills, and interests in order to help with the transition to the advertising and public relations professions.  Students attain appropriate certifications, develop and curate their portfolios, and polish interviewing strategies while developing plans for their careers.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: permission of Department of Strategic Communication administrator.  Specific issues requiring independent or small group research and study in strategic communication.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites:  STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, 32403, and 35503.  This elective course presents a practical examination of theories, models, fundamentals, and processes used in the development of effective advertising copy and its important role in strategic communication.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, and 35503.   Students learn and practice writing features, opinion pieces and other reports for target audiences.  Emphasis on developing style, content and structure for a variety of print and digital formats for target audiences.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, 32403, and 35503.  This course presents theories and models from psychology, sociology, marketing and communications to examine consumers -- how they react to advertising and promotion and their subsequent consumer behavior.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite:  A grade of C or higher in each of the gateway courses; STCO 23113 and 23123; and a combined GPA of 2.5 or higher in these courses; and a C- or higher in MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 (Statistics) or equivalent. An exploration and study of historical and current sports advertising, sports in advertising, licensing, endorsements, team promotion and marketing, and career paths. Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: permission of instructor.  For strategic communication majors, must be a junior or senior who has successfully completed required gateway courses STCO 23113 and 23123 with a C or higher in each, and a combined GPA of 2.5 in these courses, plus six upper-level hours in the major.  Related majors are also eligible to apply.  Students work 9 hours weekly on client projects and also attend a one-hour weekly class in Roxo, TCU's student agency for advertising and public relations.  Students learn agency operations, professional roles, work practices and industry trends.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites:  STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, 32403, and 35503.  Study of media influence on gender roles and how women working in media affect perceptions about gender roles.  Course explores changing expectations about women's and men's participation in leadership, communication, organizations and global issues.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, and 35503.  Introduces the fields of advertising and public relations in new media.  Topics covered include digital persuasion techniques, interactive media theory, new media planning and measurement, analytics, social media and interactive design considerations.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites:  STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, 23113, 23123, 32403, and 35503.  Social media for Strategic Communication is an upper-level course dedicated to exploring new emerging technologies and media influencing business, marketing, public relations, and advertising practices and research.

Prerequisites:  STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, and 35503.  Introduces how global brands are communicated and positioned to target audiences through marketing communications, including advertising, public relations and sales promotions.   Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, and 35503.  An analytical approach to media planning, implementing and evaluation brand strategy within a multichannel context (broadcasting, print, digital, non-traditional, social media, mobile marketing, direct marketing or alternative media.)  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, 32403, and 35503.  Legal responsibilities, rights and restrictions in advertising and public relations.  Survey of Constitutional guarantees, corporate and commercial speech, privacy, copyright, libel and defamation, plus guidelines and laws related to federal agencies, financial disclosure, deceptive advertising, and other issues.  Professional ethics codes and ethical models will also be discussed.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, 32403, and 35503, and junior standing.  Examines the global Corporate Social Responsibility movement and explores its challenges.  Students examine how to bridge successful partnerships between corporations and causes, how to improve the quality of life for employees and communities and to measure outcomes.  Students will embark on a hands-on project that uses their communication and leadership skills.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, 32403, and 35503, and junior standing.  Examines ethical issues and professional codes used in advertising, public relations and media.  Students will look critically at current professional practices to develop an understanding of prominent ethical questions.  Legal responsibilities and guidelines will also be discussed.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, 32403, and 35503.  Examines sources, media delivery systems and the impact of globally conveyed information in different cultural contexts.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, and 35503.  Non-majors require permission of instructor.  This course covers the way issues of public concerns are detected by news media and strategic communication professionals, how communication of government policies as well as corporate and nonprofit organizations' concerns affect public opinion, and analyzes a variety of crises, using real cases as examples.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: STCO 11103 or 21103, 16103 or 26103, and 35503.  Use of the case study method to scrutinize organizational events and problems to discover best practices and solutions, based on theory, principles and models related to public relations and advertising.  Course content may focus on advocacy and public affairs cases when the Texas Legislature is in session.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in each of the gateway courses: STCO 23113 (Advertising) and STCO 23123 (Public Relations), and a combined GPA of 2.5 or higher in these courses; at least 12 hours completed in the major, with a C or higher in each course; sophomore standing, and permission of instructor.  Practical experience in advertising, public relations, or related communication disciplines in a workplace setting.  The course may be taken multiple times in segments of one, two or three hours per semester, with a minimum of 75 hours worked for each semester hour credit.  A maximum credit of six hours can apply to the major.  Additional hours earned can apply as generic electives towards the required number of hours needed to graduate.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: Permission of instructor and completion of STCO 43333 (Roxo Agency) with an A- grade or higher.  Variable credit of up to three credit hours.  Students continue learning agency operations and work with clients in Roxo, TCU's student agency for advertising and public relations. Internship hours are based on 75 hours of client work for each credit hour earned; students may repeat the course to earn a maximum of six credit hours.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: STCO 11103, 16103, 32403, and 35503.  Students learn how the various communication functions -- including advertising, public relations, marketing, direct response, sales promotion and supportive communication -- can be integrated for maximum effectiveness in a variety of settings.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: Senior standing plus STCO 45413 (Channel Planning), STCO 35503 (Research) and STCO 35413 (Creative Strategy) and instructor approval.  Campaign participants are selected after an application process. For Marketing majors: senior standing and permission of instructor.  Students research, plan, create, execute and evaluate an advertising campaign for a national client, as part of the American Advertising Federation National Student Advertising Competition.  Crosslisted as MARK 40713.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: Senior standing, plus STCO 32403 (Design), STCO 31423 (Strategic Writing) and STCO 35503 (Research) and instructor approval. Students research, plan, create, execute and evaluate a multimedia campaign for a designated client.  Participation in the Public Relations Student Society of America Bateman Case Study Competition.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: Senior standing; STCO 32403 (Design); STCO 35503 (Research); and STCO 45413 (Channel Planning) or STCO 47533 (Case Studies).  Working in a team to research, plan, create, execute and evaluate a multimedia strategic communication campaign for a designated client.  Students will utilize their accumulated knowledge from their major courses.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites:  Preference is given to juniors and seniors.  Permission of instructor and/or department chair.  This course develops the student's ability to analyze, establish and execute external and internal communication goals, strategies and tactics for a client.  Students use research, discussion, peer evaluation and instructor assessment to produce creative and effective solutions to marketing and promotion challenges.  The course places students in the role of communication professionals working with the Bob Schieffer College of Communication and other TCU academic units and organizations as their clients.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

This course presents theories and models from psychology, sociology, marketing and communications to examine consumers -- how they react to advertising and promotion and their subsequent consumer behavior.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Seminar designed to explore the history of strategic communication.  Issues discussed in this class will improve historical knowledge about the mass media and give a foundation for understanding the professional development of strategic communication.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites: Open to graduate students in Strategic Communication.  Undergraduate students must have passed STCO 46403 (Law) with a grade of C or higher and must have permission of the instructor.  Advanced media law course for students focusing on contemporary challenges faced by strategic communication professionals.  The course emphasizes how the law of mass communication has adapted to new and emerging technologies such as the Internet and social media, with a particular focus on privacy, access to information, and intellectual property.  Students will learn and apply normative legal research methods to answer modern questions relevant to professional communicators. Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisites:  Permission of administrator in the Department of Communication.  Specific issues requiring independent or small group research and study in strategic communication.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.

Prerequisite: Grade of C or higher in each of the gateway courses: STCO 11103, STCO 16103, STCO 23113, and STCO 23123 and a combined GPA of 2.5 or higher in these courses, or Graduate admission.  Non-majors require permission of the instructor.  This course examines the way issues of public concerns are detected by news media and strategic communication professionals as the issues develop, and it examines how the crisis management and communication of government , corporate and nonprofit organizations' concerns affect public perceptions and opinions.  The course emphasizes practical application of theories, strategies and tactics of communicating to multiple stakeholders in crisis situations.  Students must earn a C or higher in each strategic communication course required for credit toward completion of STCO major degree requirements.
General Transfer Credit with TCUCC-FAR credit.
General Transfer Credit
Students will explore the varied culture of professional and community theatres in the Fort Worth area.
Generic Theatre credit for HT credit.
An introductory course in theatre focusing on production, performance, dramatic literature and history.

An introductory course in musical theatre focusing on production, performance, musical theatre literature and history.  Students enrolled in honors section must also enroll in Survey of Musical Theatre honors zero hour lab section to receive honors credit.
This course explores new voices in American theatre with a focus on the work of contemporary playwrights from 1970's to present.
Department permission required. An introductory course for theatre majors exploring the various components of theatre theory and production.

Department Permission required. An introductory course in technical theatre focusing on theory and practice of basic scenery construction, rigging, and safety for the theatre.  A lab is required for this class.
An introductory course in technical theatre focusing on reading and producing ground plans, elevations, section drawings, light plots, figure drawings, and perspective drawings.
Department Permission required.  An introductory course in practical makeup.  Exploring makeup design principals and application techniques, character research and development.

An introductory course in costume construction focusing on jobs in the industry and the functioning of a Costume Studio, sewing, fabrics, and the procedures for theatrical costuming.  An integrated lab is required for this class.

A beginner course in which students explore the various ways in which a designer approaches their craft.  From ideation & analysis to communication & delivery of final designs, students will learn how to work from a script, research and develop ideas, as well as present design proposals for Scenic, Costume, Lighting & Sound.
An introductory course focusing on the theory and practice of basic scenery construction, rigging, stage lighting, and safety in the theatre.  A lab is required for this class.
Department Permission required.  Students will be introduced to and apply foundational techniques of acting through scene study, text analysis, and solo performance.

Open only to BFA theatre majors with emphases in Acting, Musical Theatre, or Theatre Studies or permission of instructor. Students will be introduced to and apply foundational techniques of acting through scene study, text analysis, and solo performance.

Prerequisites: permission of instructor.  An introductory course in musical theatre performance to acquaint students with technique, analysis, literature, and professional practices.  This course may be repeated for credit.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
The examination and analysis of the structure and content of scripts for interpretation and conceptualization for theatre directors, designers, actors, and technicians.
An introductory course in Stage Management covering the duties of the modern stage manager and the process of designing sound effects and music selections for theatre productions.

Prerequisite: THEA 11313 Open only to BFA theatre majors with emphases in Acting, Musical Theatre or Theatre Studies, or permission of instructor.  An intermediate course in acting focusing on realism and scene work.

Prerequisite: Open only to BFA Theatre Majors with emphases in Acting, Musical Theatre or Theatre Studies, or permission of instructor.  A performance course focused on somatic attunement, proprioception, character embodiment, and movement analysis in service to physical storytelling.

Prerequisite: Open only to BFA theatre majors with emphases in Acting, Musical Theatre, Theatre Studies, or permission of instructor. A laboratory course for actors focusing on development of breath, resonance,  articulation, focus and intention, and their application to performance.

Prerequisites: THEA 21423, or 21433, or permission of the instructor.  Students will explore different rendering and artistic media used to produce visuals for the purpose of efficiently communicating elements of scenic, costume and lighting designs.  Processes and skills developed will be introduced in both traditional and digital platforms.
An introductory course in stage lighting focusing on design and practice.

A drawing class that also examines major epochs and cultures through the lens of the stage and production designer in developing an understanding of global history and the development of its artifacts as it is told visually.  This course covers the periods of The Ancients through Mannerism.

A drawing class that also examines major epochs and cultures through the lens of the stage and production designer in developing an understanding of global history and the development of its artifacts as it is told visually.  This course covers the periods of Baroque through the 20th Century.
Department Permission Required. Practical experience and application of skills in all areas of theatre production, related directly to Theatre TCU productions. May be repeated for credit.
Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor. A variable credit course offering practical experience in acting for students cast in Theatre TCU productions. May be repeated for credit.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
Prerequisite: Upper division status (at least 54 hours completed) and permission of instructor. Individual honors projects for theatre students who are enrolled in the TCU Honors Program.
Prerequisites:  ENGL 10803 and 20803.  History of western theatre from its origins in ancient Greece to the Spanish Golden Age.
Prerequisites:  ENGL 10803 and 20803.  History of western theatre from the French Neo-Classic Period to today.

A theatre history course focusing on the cultures (art, music, architecture, religion) of those historical periods which figure prominently in Theatre: classical Greece and Rome, Gothic/Renaissance/Elizabethan, 17th, 18th and 19th Centuries, and early and late 20th Century.
Department Permission required. Study and practice in the art of writing plays for the theatre, including dramatic structure, dialogue and characterization.  This course may be repeated for credit.

A course exploring the use of industry standard CAD systems in 2D and 3D drafting for the stage.  Concentration on theatre specific technical drawings, lighting diagrams, and detail drawings using the USITT Recommended best practices as revised in 2022.

An advanced course in technical theatre focusing on painting scenery for the stage.  This class explores application, color, and problem solving for the most used styles and attempts towards realism as they have developed through history.

Prerequisites: THEA 11233 or permission of instructor.  An advanced production course in costume construction and technology techniques including pattern making, draping (pattern development), millinery (hat making), and other specialties such as mask making and fabric dying.

Prerequisite: Open only to BFA Theatre Majors with emphases in Acting, or permission of instructor. A performance course for actors in which they study and practice the process of auditioning for theatre using prepared monologues, callback scenes, cold readings, and songs.
Prerequisite: THEA 21334 or permission of instructor. An advanced laboratory course focusing on vocal skills for actors.
Prerequisites: THEA 21303 or permission of instructor.  An advanced acting styles course focusing exclusively on the performance of Shakespearean scenes and monologues.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. An advanced laboratory course focusing on directing skills including script analysis, conceptualization, and staging resulting in a realized directing project.

Open only to BFA Theatre Majors with emphases in Acting, or permission of instructor. An intermediate performance class focused on the study and development of various movement techniques related to the physical connection to text for actors.

Prerequisite:  THEA 21333 or permission of instructor.  An intermediate performance class focused on further analysis, exploration, and application of vocal skills in performance as well as vocal health.

Prerequisite: Open only to BFA Theatre Majors with emphases in Acting, or by permission of instructor.  An advanced performance class focused on the study and development of various movement techniques, styles, and skills related to the physical development of character on stage.
Prerequisite: THEA 31363 or permission of the instructor.  An advanced performance class focused on expanding the actor's vocal dexterity and presence in performance.

Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  An intermediate/advanced course in Scene Design exploring the elements and principles of design as applied to live performance.  Students will explore the process of analyzing a narrative through a designer's lens, developing ideas, translating those ideas into physical elements, discuss and apply research methods and presentation techniques, ultimately designing and presenting a preliminary scenic package for a scripted narrative.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. An advanced course focusing on costume design through script analysis, historical and contemporary research, and character development.

This course introduces students to the elements and principles of prop design, research and execution.  Over the course of the semester, students will explore the process of script & character analysis, research & fabrication, and methods & strategies for addressing specific story challenges related to physical properties.

Prerequisite:  THEA 21413 or permission of instructor.  An advanced design course specializing in the use of lighting to enhance a theatrical production. Concentration on the aesthetic of stage lighting, design styles such as dance and busking, and programming lighting consoles.
A laboratory dance class in musical theatre styles.  Specific styles may vary by semester.  May be repeated for credit.
Prerequisites: permission of instructor.  A course in music theory specifically designed for the issues most commonly faced in Musical Theatre.

Prerequisites: Completion of two semesters of THEA 11502 or permission of instructor.  An intermediate-level course focused on developing the song audition book, era by era, to acquaint students with technique, repertoire and professional practices.  This course may be repeated for credit.

Prerequisite:  THEA 31503 or permission of instructor.  An intermediate exploration of the components of written music crucial to the musical theatre performer, designed to assist students in understanding and applying the written language of music.
This course is designed to assist non-Musical Theatre emphasis students in expanding and honing their musical theatre performance and audition skills.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  Off-campus theater internships.  May be repeated for credit.

This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

This course is designed to teach students advanced skills in reading and understanding dramatic literature by providing a thematic study of various topics and/or writers.  This course may be repeated for credit.

Prerequisites: THEA 11243 or THEA 11203 or THEA 21413 or Permission of instructor. A project-based course focusing on established and emerging industrial technologies used in the production and execution of the performing arts.
Prerequisites: THEA 31000 or permission of instructor.  Individual honors projects for senior theatre students who are enrolled in the TCU Honors Program.

Prerequisite: Students must be prepared to graduate by May of current academic year. Open only to BFA majors with an emphasis in Acting or Musical Theatre, or by permission of instructor. This course prepares students to enter the professional audition world of the entertainment business through a perfection of their audition acting, singing and dancing skills.

Prerequisite: permission of instructor.  A course for BFA Theatre majors in which they consider and explore what kinds of professional theatre careers or graduate school training they intend to pursue;  students prepare themselves for professional careers by developing such items as resumes, portfolios, audition material, and headshots.
An advanced lecture course covering the major historical periods of Western dress, focusing on the stage.

Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  An experiential theatre course, usually taught abroad.  Students attend theatre productions and meet with theatre professionals as well as visit other cultural sites.  This course may be repeated for credit.

A theatre history course focusing on Musical Theatre in the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries, including the development of the form, major artists who contributed to it, and seminal musical theatre works.

Prerequisite: Open only to BFA Theatre Majors, or by permission of instructor.  Devised theatre, frequently called Collective Creation, is a method of theatre making in which the script or performance score originates from collaborative, often improvisatory work by a performing ensemble.  Working from a prompt (idea, theme, or concept) our process includes five key stages; research, development, documentation, rehearsal, and performance.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  A directed study in theatre occurring in London.  1-3 credits.  May be repeated for credit.

Prerequisite: THEA 31303 or permission of instructor. An advanced course in acting focused on fulfilling the performance demands of historical genres of drama, ranging from ancient Greek Tragedy to 19th Century Comedy.

Prerequisite: Open only to BFA Theatre Majors with an emphasis in Acting, or by permission of instructor. This course will explore the basic rules and moves of Hand-to-hand Unarmed Stage Combat by focusing on theory, practice, and application.  Stage Combat moves learned in this course are based on the Society of American Fight Directors' Unarmed Regulations.
Prerequisite: THEA 31363, or permission of instructor.  An advanced acting course focusing on aquiring, analyizing, and performing a variety of dialects and accents.
Prerequisite: Open only to BFA Theatre Majors with emphases in Acting, or permission of instructor.  A performance course focused on the study of acting technique related to film and television.

Prerequisite:  Open only to BFA Theatre Majors with an emphasis in Acting, or by permission of instructor.  An advanced performance course focused on the study of voice acting and through applied lessons in sound editing, voice-demo creation, audiobook & commercial narration, and acting in animated media.

Prerequisite: Open only to upper-division BFA Theatre majors with an emphasis in Acting, or by permission of instructor.  An advanced performance course focused on building a character, building a scene, playing the style, emphasizing methods of achieving truthful behavior on the stage.

Prerequisites:  THEA 21423, 21433, and or permission of instructor.  This is a practical workshop class, allowing student designers, technicians and their mentors to work together on the research and development of practical theatrical designs and technical elements in theatre.  This course may be repeated for credit.

Prerequisite: two semesters of THEA 11502, two semesters of THEA 31512, or permission of instructor.  An advanced acting/musical theatre course focusing on the refinement of performance skills and professional practices.  This course may be repeated for credit.
Prerequisites: THEA 41503 or permission of instructor.  An advanced acting course focusing on the integration of singing and acting in performance.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  Independent theatre research or performance projects  1-3 credits.  May be repeated for credit.

Prerequisites: Permission of instructor.  A variety of special or one-time topics in Theatre may be covered in this class, and the format may vary including lecture, performance, activity, or research courses. 1-3 semester hours.  This course may be repeated for credit.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. A directed study in theatre focusing on projects in acting.  1-3 credits.  May be repeated for credit.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. A directed study in theatre focusing on projects in directing.  1-3 credits.  May be repeated for credit.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  A directed study in theatre focusing on projects in scenic design.  1-3 credits.  May be repeated for credit.
Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  A directed study in theatre focusing on projects in costume design.  1-3 credits.  May be repeated for credit.
Prerequisite: permission of instructor.  A directed study in theatre focusing on projects in lighting design.  1-3 credits.  May be repeated for credit.

Prerequisites: permission of instructor.  A directed study in theatre focusing on projects in production including stage management, technical direction, carpentry, costume technology, electrics, and other production topics.
General Transfer Credit
General Transfer Credit
General Transfer Credit
General Transfer Credit

This one-hour course for first-semester students provides knowledge and skills to help students successfully transition into the academic community at TCU.  With an Instructor and Peer Guide, students in the course explore the nature and purpose of higher education, critical thinking, goal-setting, time-management and stress-management, campus resources, and learning in a diverse community, among other topics.
